characters: HOOKER AND GONDORFF IN THE STORE OFFICE AGAIN
THE FLOOR AREA OF THE STORE
THE F.B.I. CARS ON THEIR WAY
THE OUTER PART OF THE BAR AGAIN
COMING INTO A POOR MAN'S GAMBLING JOINT

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: A white on black TITLE appears in the lower left hand cor of the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bleak, windy morning, the kind that clears the streets of all but the winos (who carry their own heaters and the point-men for juvenile gangs.  We pick up a solit figure, Joe Mottola, coming down the street and entering what appears to be an abandoned tenement.  He pauses a second to dust his white-winged alligator shoes on the ba of his pants leg.  Sharply dressed and surrounded by the aura of one who is making money for the first time and broadcasting it on all bands, he seems an incongruity in this part of town. We follow him up a flight of rickety stairs to a second floor flat.  He knocks on the door, is admitted by a caut doorman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly we are plunged into a room of chattering, clamor people.  This is a spot for the numbers racket, a place immune from legal interference, where any sucker can bet a number between 1 and 1000 in the hope of getting the 60 to 1 payoff that goes to those few who guess right.  The bettors are queued up in several lines before a long tabl where they place their bets and are given receipts in ret Others wait at a cashier's window to pick up previous earnings or to ask for credit. Mottola moves through the crowd to a back room where bett slips are being sorted and money counted under the watchf and somewhat impatient gaze of a Supervisor, an older man named Mr. Granger.  The Yankee-White Sox game is heard on the radio in the background. Mottola, noticing that his entrance has aroused little interest, saunters over to the Phone Girl and gives her a little pinch on the cheek.  The girl slaps his hand away, obviously having been through this before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat it, Mottola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granger glances up and exchanges a token nod with Mottola who plops down in a folding chair next to the radio.  The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8720...Yes, hold on a second. (calling over to the Supervisor) Mr. Granger, Chicago on the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granger is a little apprehensive about talking to Chicago but takes the phone anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flabby, bald man named Combs is on the other end of the line.  Visible beyond the door and interior window of his office is a large room, cluttered with tables, typewriter clerks and adding machines.  This room is the clearinghou for all the transaction of the numbers game.  All the betting slips and income from the spots are brought in he and processed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granger, this is Combs.  Why haven't we heard from ya?  Everybody else is in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had a few problems with the Law this morning.  The Mayor promised the Jaycees to get tough on the rackets again, so he shut everybody down for a couple hours to make it look good.  Nothing serious, it just put us a little behind for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been making your payoffs, haven't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yes.  He does this every year. There's nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, finish your count and get it up here as soon as you can.  I don't wanta be here all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, the Man's gonna be real happy.  Looks like we cleared over ten grand this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not impressed) We cleared 22 here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, you got the whole Chicago south side.  How do ya expect the eight lousy spots I've got to compete with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading off a sheet of paper on his desk) They did 14 grand in Evanston, 16.5 is Gary, and 20 in Cicero.  Looks like you're bringing up the rear, Granger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granger burns inside.  One of the girls who's been sortin and counting hands him a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got the count.  We'll put the take on the 4:15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be waitin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs hangs up, smiling to himself, proud of the way he g the needle to Granger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granger storming over to a safe and jerking open the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping) Mottola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola hustles out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a bundle of bills) Take this up to the city on the 4:15.  They'll be waitin' for it at the clearing house.  And don't stop for no drinks.  You can get a cab down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola takes the money and slips it into his inside coat pocket with all the dramatic flair of the true flunky.  N one would ever guess that he was just an overdressed messenger boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola emerges from a side entrance into a narrow alley. He walks briskly down to the end and turns left into a la alleyway; this one connecting two streets.  The alley is deserted save for one scruffy, slovenly dressed young stranger coming toward him from the opposite direction. man carries a battered suitcase and seems to be in a hurr Suddenly, Mottola hears shouting coming from somewhere behind him.  He turns around to see a small, weathered looking thief come racing around the corner and down the alley toward him, frantically pursued by a gray-haired bl man.  Limping noticeably, the black man manages a few cri for help and then stumbles and falls.  The stranger yells Mottola to cover his side of the alley, and then readies himself for the arrival of the thief.  Mottola just stand there, not the least interested in the exercise of justic Just as the thief is about to run on by, the stranger thr his suitcase at the little man's legs, sending him sprawl and separating him from the wallet he's been carrying in left hand. The stranger makes a dash for the wallet and kicks it bac to where Mottola is standing.  Almost by reflex, Mottola picks it up.  The thief scrambles to his feet and starts back toward his new-found enemy, brandishing a knife.  Bo the stranger and Mottola brace themselves for an attack. The thief, realizing that there are two people to fight, begins to think better of it.  He is not a young man, nor particularly strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his fist at the stranger) You fuckin' nigger-lover.  I'll get you for this someday, sucker egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola and the stranger exchange glances of relief as th thief flees out onto the street and disappears. The black man, meanwhile, has struggled to his feet and i staggering toward them.  He collapses against the alley w after a few steps.  The stranger rushes over to him, foll somewhat absently by Mottola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wallet.  You gotta go after him. He's got all the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we got the wallet. What happened?  He get ya with the knife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stranger opens the Black Man's coat to reveal a blood wound at the top of his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to move) Give it to me!  Please.  I gotta know it's all there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just sit tight, old man.  We're gonna have to get you to a doctor. (starting to leave) I'll call a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no cops!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola has given him his wallet, which the black man now opens, disclosing a fat bundle of bills tied by a rubber band.  Mottola and the stranger are amazed by the amount money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little uneasy) You wanted by the law or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, it's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy carryin' that kinda money in this neighborhood.  No wonder you got hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get to his feet) Thanks.  I'm obliged to ya, but I gotta get goin'. (his leg gives way under him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't goin' nowhere on that leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta!  Look, I run some slots down in West Bend for a mob here. I got a little behind on my payoffs so they figure I been holdin' out on 'em.  They gave me to 4:00 to come up with the cash.  I don't get it there I'm dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It don't look good, gramps, it's ten of now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a hundred bucks for you and your friend if you deliver the money for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitates) I dunno.  That little mug that got ya is mad enough at me already -- what if he's out there waitin' around a corner with some friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't know you're carryin' it. C'mon, you gotta help me out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (makes up his mind) Sorry, pal.  I'll fix you up, call you a doc, but I ain't gonna walk into a bunch of knives for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (desperate to Mottola) How bout you?  I'll give you the whole hundred!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think you can trust him?  He didn't do shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, butt out, chicken liver.  I gave him back his wallet, didn't I? (to black man) How far is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1811 Mason.  Put it in Box 3C.  You won't have no trouble.  There's five thousand dollars there and here's a hundred for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the bundle of bills from the black man, plus the $100 bill) All right.  I'll make your drop for you, old man.  And don't worry, you can trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola puts the bills in his inside coat pocket, right n to the numbers money.  The stranger, who has now finished bandaging, watches him do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that punk and his pals decide to search ya, you'll never fool 'em carryin' it there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly afraid again) What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a bag or somethin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a handkerchief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stranger goes into the right coat pocket and pulls ou wrinkled handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola takes out the Black Man's five grand and hands it the Stranger.  He puts it in the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better stick that other in here too, if you wanta keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading) Just hurry, will ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola pulls out the numbers money and puts it in the handkerchief too.  The stranger ties it all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating by slipping the bundle down into crotch) All right.  Carry it down in your pants here. (pulling it back out and tucking it in Mottola's pants) Ain't no hard guy in the world gonna frisk ya there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (to the black man) So long, partner.  Don't worry, everything's gonna be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Black Man nods gratefully, but there's still a trace worry on his face.  Mottola trots off down the alley and onto the street, glancing around cautiously for signs of trouble.  He walks hurriedly down the sidewalk toward the cab stand in the distance.  Suddenly the little man with knife appears out of a doorway about 15 yards behind him. Mottola notices him and quickens his pace, finally breaki into a dead run. We follow him as he dashes headlong down the street, open a big lead on the guy with the knife.  He reaches the tax zone.  He hops in a cab and slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jumps in, closes the door, and breathes a sigh of reli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way is Mason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About 20 blocks south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go north.  The Joliet Station -- Fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola settles back in his seat and starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just made the world's easiest five grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the bundle out from inside his pants in order to gaze upon his new-found fortune.  He unties the handkerch It's full of toilet paper.  Mottola looks like he's just been shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: hightailing it down the street, two newly solvent con artists on the lam.  It's hard to run they're laughing so hard.  The stranger chucks his suitcase in a trash can an pulls the real handkerchief out of his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, what a bundle.  Did you know he was that loaded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no, I just cut into him.  I woulda settled for pawning one of them shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they split off, music begins, and we go into a

dialogues.speaker: TITLES SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Done to a driving Chicago blues, the sequence is designed establish somewhat the milieu of the stranger, known to friends and enemies alike as Hooker.  We see the followin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is getting a radio and well-worn suit out of hook. It's like seeing old friends again.  All pantomime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shabby little place he rents above a cigar store.  We p him up in a jerry-built outdoor shower, which he's rigged on the fire escape.  The rinse water drips down through t landing into the grimy alley below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing) 'With plenty of money and you-oo- oo, Oh baby, what I wouldn't do-oo- oo...'

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET AGAIN
dialogues.text: jauntily carrying a magnum of champagne and some flowers, obviously on his way to see someone special.

dialogues.speaker: IN A BURLESQUE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Hooker stands in the wings holding the flowers and champa watching his date for the evening, a 6'3" stripper named Crystal, do her routine. Crystal finishes up and comes off the stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired) Hi, Hooker, you gettin' married or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come into a little dough.  You wanna get outa here tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't.  I got a 10 o'clock show.  I need the five bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll spend fifty on ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crystal looks at him a second and starts to giggle.  We'r pretty sure she's gonna get outa here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: COMING INTO A POOR MAN'S GAMBLING JOINT
dialogues.text: Little more than a reconverted brick basement, the place contains three shoddy, homemade roulette tables.  Hooker, accompanied now by Crystal, nods a greeting to the doorma and proceeds to a table where there are already several other people laying their bets for the next spin.  Hooker knows the wheel man, an old-timer named Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glad to see him) Hooker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin', Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (collecting bets and paying off the winners) Ain't seen you in months, boy. Thought maybe you took a fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, just a little hard times, that's all.  It's all over now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna have a go here? (pointing to the betting board) How 'bout a ten spot on the line here.  The 4-9 been lookin' good today.  Lotsa action on 28th Street down there, too.  Pay ya 10-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jimmy finishes his spiel, he starts the wheel spinning and drops in the ball.  Betting is allowed to continue un the ball drops from the outer ring into the center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out his wallet) Three grand on the black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy is stunned.  The others at the table, used to dolla bets, look at Hooker like he's some kind of foreign digni

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) You sure you wanna start off that big?  Bet like that could put a real dent in us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel lucky tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, come on, Hooker, why don't you just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three grand on the black, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy wants to argue some more, but the ball is getting ready to drop into the center.  We see Jimmy quickly pres hidden lever under the table with his foot.  The ball fal and settles into red 27 with a motion that is not quite right.  The others at the table fail to notice, but Hooke is not fooled.  He stares venomously at Jimmy, who knows that Hooker is on to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Hooker. (making an attempt at levity, in order to explain) Good thing that ball came up red. Guy could get in trouble around here, losin' a bet that big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy reaches for Hooker's money.  Hooker stops him by putting his hand on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spin it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy doesn't know what the hell to do.  He gives Hooker little head motion to indicate a small window high up in of the walls.  Behind it, we see a pair of eyes.  Suddenl Hooker understands why Jimmy had to cheat him, but it doesn't change his demand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spin it anyway, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy is beside himself.  If he doesn't spin again, Hooke may expose him.  If he does spin, and loses, his manageme will fire him.  He pleads to Hooker with his eyes, but it no use.  Jimmy spins the wheel and reluctantly drops in t ball.  This time there is no foot on the lever, and it settles into black 15.  Hooker stares at the ball a secon and then looks up at his terrified friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, pal.  I knew it was my night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker pushes the money over to Jimmy and walks out of th room.  He's lost $3,000, but he's still working on a luck night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Crystal out on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Thanks for the evening, Hooker.  I can still make the 10 o'clock.  If you wanna spend 50 bucks on me again, mail it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going into his pocket for more money) Hey wait a minute. (he comes up with 30В›) Aw, the hell with ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A late model Ford roars up and screeches to a stop in fro of the plant.  Out bursts a carefully-groomed, tight-lipp young man named Greer, who hustles into the plant.  We follow him through a maze of machinery to the service elevator and up to the third floor where we find ourselve in the clearinghouse room we saw earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The working day is over now, and everyone has gone, excep for Combs, who sits somberly in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found Mottola.  He was drunk in a dive in Joliet.  Never got on the train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aggravated) I don't wanta hear about his day, Greer.  What happened to the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lost it to a coupla con artists on his way outa the spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve thousand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs sits in quiet thought for a second.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Better get on the phone to New York.  See what the big mick wants to do about it. (pause) I gotta pretty good idea, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An agitated young man, Floyd, weaves his way through the craps and roulette tables, and hustles up a staircase to second floor room with a drawing of a snarling tiger on t door.  Below the tiger, the word "FARO" appears.  There i large man, of thuggish demeanor, guarding the door, but Floyd gives him a small hand signal and walks right by hi

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE FARO ROOM
dialogues.text: In the center is a beautifully-carved wooden table, on wh sit a faro board and a dealing box, tended by a stone-fac Dealer, who calls the progress of the game in a continuou abacus-like device that keeps track of the cards which ha already been played.  On the opposite side of the table, completely absorbed in the rhythmic appearance of the car from the dealing box, sits Doyle Lonnegan.  Although is clothes and accessories are those of a wealthy man, there a coarseness to both his movement and speech which bespea lower class origins, for which he now has nothing but contempt. Floyd enters the room and approaches him cautiously, tryi hard to make as little noise as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle, can I see you a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up from the table) I'm busy, Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's important.  We had a little trouble in Chicago today.  One of our runners got hit for 12 grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mottola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure he didn't just pocket it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we checked his story with a tipster.  He was cleaned by two grifters on 47th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They workin' for anybody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Could be.  We're runnin' that down now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, mark Mottola up a little and put him on a bus.  Nothin' fancy, just enough to keep him from coming back.  Get some local people to take care of the other two. (impassively) We gotta discourage this kinda thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker, still in his suit, but looking a little worse for wear, knocks on the door of one of the apartments.  A you black woman, Louise, answers the door, holding a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Howdy, Louise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (admiring Hooker in his suit) Goddamn, Johnny Hooker, you're a sharp hunky in them linens.  If you wasn't so pale, I'da sworn you had class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker steps inside and walks right into a big hug from a older black woman, Alva.  Alva has a hat on, obviously ju about to go out.  Beyond her we see the Eirie kid and the Black Man (known from here on as Luther Coleman) playing game of mah jong on the dining table with a man whose bac is to us.  An 11-year-old boy is listening to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that down, Leroy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Johnny, Luther said you was somethin' to see today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never be as good as that mark, Alva.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we gonna hear all about it when we get back from church. Leroy, get your jacket on, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy goes to get his jacket.  Louise is finished putting the baby to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You goin' to church now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They been havin' late bingo down there.  I'm gonna call on the Lord for a little cash, while he's still payin' off.  Luther, you look in on that child from time to time, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther nods that he will.  Alva, Leroy and Louise leave f church as Hooker strolls over and tosses two packets on t table.  Luther doesn't pick his up, but the other man doe We now see that he is the thief in the opening sequence. is called the Eirie kid and he is delighted at his share.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Luther told me he was carrying a wad, but I didn't figure this much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way did he do, Eirie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight north.  He was gonna take it all and run.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) The bastard.  He can blow his nose all the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh again, but Luther doesn't share their enthusia He watches Hooker who becomes uncomfortable under his gaz

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.  Where you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flopping into a chair) I had some appointments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not fooled) How much did ya lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) All of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed) In one goddamn night?  What are ya sprayin' money around like that for? You coulda been nailed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I checked the place out.  There weren't no dicks in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a con man, and you blew it like a pimp.  I didn't teach ya to be no pimp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's eatin' you?  I've blown money before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No class grifter woulda' done it, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think my play is bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's the best...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker sinks back, embarrassed that he misread Coleman's intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's the only reason I ain't quit before now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' too slow for this racket.  I done the best I'm gonna do.  You hang on too long, you start embarrassin' yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talkin' about?  We just took off the biggest score we've ever had.  We can do anything we want now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothin' compared to what you could be makin' on the Big Con. You're wastin' your time workin' street marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey look.  You think I'm gonna run out on ya or somethin'?  Just cause we hit it big.  Luther, I owe you everything.  If you hadn't taught me con, I wouldn't know nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) Aw hell, you sound like some goddamn sucker.  You know everything I know.  You got nothin' more to learn from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you played the Big Con.  You said it was nothin'.  A game for flakes and mama's boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm tellin' ya now, you're a fool if you don't get into it.  A bigger fool than I was. (pause, holding up the money) I been lookin' for this one all my life, Johnny.  Now I got a chance to step out at the top.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker knows it's no use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a long silence) What the hell you gonna do with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I got a brother down in K.C., runs a freight outlet.  I can go halfsies with 'em!  It ain't too exciting, but it's mostly legal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker just nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straighten up, kid.  I wouldn't turn ya out if ya weren't ready. (flipping Hooker a piece of paper) I got a guy named Henry Gondorff I want you to look up.  There ain't a better insideman alive.  He'll teach ya everything ya gotta know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll take a cut of what I make, won't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm out, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's the way you want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way I want it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late at night now.  Hooker and Eirie wander along th street together, not really ready to go home, but with no other ideas either.  Hooker, obviously preoccupied, idly strikes a match on a street lamp as he passes and lets it burn out.  He does this several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like that Coleman, huh? After three years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw come on, it was the only thing to do.  He knew he was holdin' ya back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were partners.  If it weren't for Luther I'd still be hustlin' pinball down at Gianelli's.  I don't need anything more than I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't gonna have nothin' if you don't lay off them games of chance. There's a depression on ya know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's always a depression on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you saved a little, you wouldn't have to grift so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like griftin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could buy yourself some things. Clothes, or a nice car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't look any good in clothes and I don't know how to drive. What else ya got to sell, Eirie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk on a few more feet, when suddenly a police car pulls up alongside them and two men jump out.  The first, uniformed policeman, grabs Eirie around the neck. Hooker makes a break for it, but the second Figure, a bur detective named Snyder, tackles him in the middle of the street, drags him back into the alley and plasters him up against a brick wall.  The two have met before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi there, Snyder.  Things a little slow down at the Bunco Department tonight, eh?  Somebody lose the dominoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scored blood money today, Hooker.  You need a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knocking Snyder's hand away) Aw, find yourself a shoplifter to roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder gives Hooker a swift knee in the thigh and follows with an elbow across the head.  Hooker flies into a row o boxes and garbage cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up slowly) You got the wrong guy, pal.  I been home with the flu all day. (rising to a fuller height) You can stake out my toilet if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang.  Snyder, infuriated by Hooker's irreverence, slams to the ground again.  The policeman is no longer holding Eirie but is almost daring him to make a move.  Eirie wan to go to Hooker's aid, but he knows the policeman will be him to a pulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling Hooker out of the heap and smashing him against the wall again) I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on 49th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled by the information) You're crazy.  I'm not stupid enough to play for rackets money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not intentionally maybe, but that don't make no difference to Lonnegan. He'll swat you like any fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll square it with the fixer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody can buy you a prayer, if I put the finger on ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder lets go.  Hooker sinks back against the wall.  He says nothing; he's waiting for the price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure your end of the score was at least 3 gees.  I want 2 no matter what it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) My end was only one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not taking the fake) Then you'll have to come up with another grand somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is beat and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reaches into his coat, pulls out a stack of bills and counts out $2000 to Snyder.  Eirie looks on in amazement; didn't think Hooker had it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pocketing the money and motioning his partner to put his gun away) You're a smart egg, Hooker.  No use dyin' for 2 grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder and his policeman friend get in their car and star down the street.  Hooker and Eirie walk nonchalantly in t other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you blew all your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.  That stuff I gave him was counterfeit.  They'll pinch him the first place he tries to spend it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder and his partner disappear around a corner.  Hooker suddenly takes off like a shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs into a drugstore and goes to the phone booth. There's already a woman in it.  Hooker rips open the door and throws her out.  Hurriedly, he begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing outside the booth) What the hell you gonna do when Snyder rushes his finger right to Lonnegan?  You're committin' suicide, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waiting for the ring) Aw Christ, it doesn't make no difference now.  If Snyder knows about it so does everybody else. He never gets anything first...Damn, there's no answer at Luther's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Hooker.  What ever you do, don't go back to your place tonight, don't go anyplace you usually go, ya hear me?  Get outa town or somethin', but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker, still getting no answer, slams the phone down and blasts out of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie chases him frantically, calling him to come back, b he's giving away too many years and there's no stopping Hooker at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pumping down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker races into Luther's brownstone, charges up to the third floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker runs up through a small group of people on the sta He bursts into Luther's room, the door of which is alread open.  The room shows signs of a struggle, a turned-over chair, a broken lamp, but there is no Coleman.  Hooker go slowly to the window.  He looks down into the courtyard a then suddenly sprints back out the door.  As we hear him scrambling down the stairs, the camera dollies to the win and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There on the concrete below, face down, is the body of Luther Coleman.  Hooker races out to it and kneels down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking the body) C'mon Luther, get up.  You gotta get up, Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the distance, sirens are heard.  Heads are out of the windows and some people are starting to gather in the courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn you, Luther, will you get up? (pounding on the body) I'm not waitin' for you, Luther. I'm not waitin' anymore.  Get up, you son of a bitch.  Goddamn you, Luther, goddamn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sirens are close now, and Hooker tears himself away f Luther and runs.  The others gather to look at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We open on Hooker sleeping in some remote corner of the station, covered with newspapers for warmth, and barely distinguishable from the clutter of junk surrounding him. station security officer, on his morning sweep, wanders b and delivers a terrific blow to the soles of Hooker's fee with a nightstick.  Hooker jolts awake with a cry of pain as the officer diffidently moves on toward another sleepi victim. Tired and sore from his night in the station, Hooker struggles to his feet and attempts to take stock of the situation.  He tries to smooth the wrinkles out of his su but it's futile.  A quick check of his wallet finds it as empty as he'd remembered it.

dialogues.speaker: THE STATION
dialogues.text: Hooker walks in and goes to the toy section.  He looks through several small novelties, till he finds what he's looking for -- a little tin replica of a policeman's badg He looks around for station detectives, and seeing none, slips the badge into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: THE STATION
dialogues.text: Hooker rinses out his mouth, towels off his face and slic his hair back with water.  It's a drop in the bucket, but seems to revitalize him a little.

dialogues.speaker: STATION
dialogues.text: We see Hooker removing a sign from a door, but the angle prohibits us from reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drops the sign in a waste can and walks out into the crowded passenger lobby.  After scanning the area careful for a minute, he goes up to a conservative young business man, who's busy reading the schedule board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing open his wallet to reveal the little tin badge and then closing it again quickly) Excuse me, sir.  Treasury Dept... I'd like to ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flustered) What for?  I haven't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station.  Have you made any purchases here today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) Yes, a ticket to Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'm afraid we'll have to impound your money until we're sure that it's all good.  Can I see your wallet and your ticket, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing them over) But I got a train to make.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking out the money and returning the wallet) It'll only take 20 minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about all these other people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing up) We'll get 'em!  Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here, ya know.  We go around advertising ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh? (pointing to his suit) You think I'm wearin' this rag here 'cause I like it?  Christ, everybody thinks life's a holiday or somethin' when you got a badge. (pouring it on) I been here since three this morning, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people.  You try to help 'em and they spit on you.  I shoulda let ya go and gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Businessman is totally shamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, really I am, but my train leaves in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll give ya a break. (pointing to a hall) Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left.  Go on in there and wait at the window. I'll take this... (he holds up the money) ...in the back and run it through right away.  We'll have you outta there in a couple minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  You don't know how much I appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a little wave) Think nothin' of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man goes off down the hall, more than grateful to be given a break like this.  Hooker heads for the "back".  W follow the Man down the hall to the unmarked door.  He strides on through to find himself face to face with a wa of busily flushing urinals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boarding the 8:10 for Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man wandering up and down the hall, wondering how he could have missed that room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street runs along side an elevated train track.  We p up Hooker coming down the street, eating a hot dog he bou with the money he just earned in the train station. He appears to be looking for an address, referring every and then to the piece of paper Luther gave him the night before.  Finally he stops in front of an old three-story building which contains a carousel on the bottom 2 floors and what appear to be apartments on the third floor.  He peers inside the big, sliding glass doors and seeing no s of life, goes around to the side to look for a way in. A 35 year-old woman, Billie, appears in her bathrobe on t second floor landing and descends the stairs to get the morning paper.  She's eating an apple.  Although she has just gotten up and looks it, she has the presence of one is probably quite striking at other hours.  The sight of Hooker fazes her not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm looking for a guy named Henry Gondorff.  You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting back up the stairs) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther Coleman sent me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie stops and comes back down the stairs.  It's the fi time she's stopped chewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking him out) You Hooker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you say so.  I thought maybe you was a copper or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to a side door and unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the room in the back.  He wasn't expecting you so soon though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's not quite sure what that means, but there's something about Billie that makes him know that you don't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker walks past the now motionless carousel to the room the back and knocks on the door.  No answer.  He gives th door a little push and it swings open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room inside if small and cluttered, consisting of a b a sink, and a bathroom, all covered by a layer of books, dirty clothes and beer bottles.  Draped over a chair, ful dressed, but completely passed out is the one and only He Gondorff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself) The great Henry Gondorff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water blasting out of the fixture.  We see Gondorff, stil fully clothed, sitting in the bottom of the shower, the spray streaming off his face.  An imposing figure, with d set eyes and full beard, he just sits there stoically, looking like a soggy lumberjack.  Hooker, sitting on the floor between the toilet and the sink, watches listlessly Finally --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn the goddamn thing off, will ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sober?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can talk, can't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker makes no move to get up.  Gondorff struggles to hi knees, turns off the water, and slumps back against the w The two men just look past each other a second.  Down in bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad to meet ya, kid.  You're a real horse's ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, Luther said you could teach me something.  I already know how to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff wipes his face with his hand.  His mood softens little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'm sorry about Luther.  He was the best street worker I ever saw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had you down as a big-timer. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, I conned a Senator from Florida on a stocks deal.  A real lop-ear. He thought he was gonna take over General Electric.  Some Chantoozie woke him up, though, and he put the feds on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you blew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) Luther didn't tell me you had a big mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't tell me you was a fuck- up, either. (Gondorff looks at him coldly) You played the Big Con since then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I lammed it around for a while while things cooled off.  Philly, Denver, Baltimore, nuthin' towns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's disappointment is obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't kid yourself, friend, I still know how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker nods, unconvinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up from the floor and emptying the water out of his pockets) You gonna stay for breakfast, or do you already know how to eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired) I picked something up on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sensing something) Lonnegan after you, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Haven't seen anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never do, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Hooker.  He hadn't thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Lonnegan, in plus fours and argyles sits on a bench as ot members of his foursome tee off.  Floyd comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got word from Chicago.  They got one of the grifters last night. The nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still looking for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got the contract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs gave it to Reilly and Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They staked out the other guy's place last night, but he never showed.  They figure maybe he skipped town.  You wanna follow 'em up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan regards Floyd patiently and then pats the bench beside him.  Floyd sits gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see the guy in the red sweater over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to one of Lonnegan's foursome, a short, squat litt Irishman in a red sweater.  He was a good-time, friendly manner and a winning Irish smile.  We like him immediatel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Danny McCoy.  No Neck McCoy we called him.  Runs a few protection rackets for Carnello while he's waiting for something bigger to come along.  Me and Danny been friends since we were six. Take a good look at that face, Floyd, cause if he ever finds out we let one lousy grifter beat us, you'll have to kill him and every other hood in Chicago who'd like to do the same thing.  You understand what I'm sayin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is called to the tee by one of his foursome.  He exchanges a friendly smile with McCoy and belts the ball down the fairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff, dried off now and in a new set of clothes, is pulling up the shades of the large facing windows of the carousel building.  The morning light pours in, illuminat fully for the first time the ornate merry-go-round and it massive oaken horses.  Hooker watches him go about his business.  Billie calls down from the mezzanine which surrounds the carousel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feeling all right this morning, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, Billie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mind opening the round a little early today?  We got some business coming in before hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff waves okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hooker) Great little countess, that Billie. Runs a good house up there, too. One of the few left that Luciano doesn't own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff walks around on the carousel, checking straps, bearing and poles.  Hooker follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting impatient) Gondorff, you gonna teach me the Big Con or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on his back, checking underneath one of the horses) You didn't act much like you wanted to learn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna play for Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) You know anything about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exploding) Yeh, he croaked Luther.  What else do I gotta know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff just sits tight and waits for him to cool off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waving Gondorff off, embarrassed at his own outburst) Aw right, he runs the numbers outta the south side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going over to start the machinery) And a packing company, a chain of Savings and Loans and half the politicians in Chicago and New York. There ain't a fix in the world gonna cool him out if he blows on ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take him anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whirling on him) Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like steel) 'Cause I don't know enough about killin' to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the right answer. Gondorff didn't know it himself un now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do it alone, ya know.  It takes a mob of guys like you and enough money to make 'em look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get by without 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't like playin' winos on the street.  You gotta do more than outrun the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incensed) I never played for winos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going right on, ignoring Hooker's remark) You gotta keep Lonnegan's con, even after you spent his money.  And no matter how much you take from his, he'll get more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sacred of 'em, aren't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right down to my socks, turkey.  If I'da been half as scared a that lop-ear, I wouldn't a fallen asleep on 'em.  Lonnegan might kill me, but at least he won't bore me to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I can find a mob that'll risk it. But no matter what happens, I don't want you comin' back to me halfway through and sayin' it's not enough... cause it's all you got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker nods.  Gondorff switches on the carousel and steps back to admire his handiwork.  The carousel makes a grind sound, does a few lurches and stops cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music begins and we are into a short:

dialogues.speaker: SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: Detailing the arrival of the others three members of Gondorff's "mob." Throughout, Gondorff wears the fedora h which is his trademark.  We begin with -- A tall, good-looking man, Kid Twist, making his way throu the railway station.  Impeccably dressed and carrying a small suitcase, he combs the terrain carefully with his e Finally he catches a glimpse of the thing he's been looki for.  It's Gondorff, standing by a newsstand.  Gondorff makes a quick snubbing motion on his nose as if flicking a gnat.  This is known among con men as the "office." Twi returns the sign with a barely discernible smile as he wa on by.  Con men rarely acknowledge each other openly in public, but it's obvious that these two are glad to see e other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker in, having his hair cut and his nails manicured. Gondorff gives instructions to the barber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is modeling a new suit in front of a mirror.  He doesn't look too pleased, but Gondorff peels out a bankro anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of white spats stepping off a bus.  We follow them into a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we tilt up to reveal J.J. Singleton, the most flamboyant of the bunch.  On his way to the check-in desk he silently exchanges the "office" with Gondorff, who is sitting on a lounge reading the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker being shown into a small apartment room by an old woman.  It consists of a bed, a table and a sink.  Hooker nods his acceptance to the woman and gives her a bill.  H takes another look around the room and decides to go out somewhere, but first he wedges a small piece of paper between the door and the jamb, about an inch off the floo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold on a slight, bespectacled teller, Eddie Niles, in the process of counting a large deposit.  Niles is all business; if he's ever smiled, no one knows about it.  He glances up for a second and sees Gondorff "officing" him from across the bank.  Without a word he shoves the money he's been counting back into the hands of a startled customer, abruptly closes up his window, flips his identification tag on the manager's desk and walks out of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room has obviously been relegated to the status of t storage room.  It contains the water heater, mops and brooms, old bed springs, etc.  In the middle of the room space has been cleared for a table, around which are seat Hooker, Gondorff, Niles, Singleton and Twist.  Gondorff i in his T-shirt, but still wears his hat.  Kid Twist is in suit as usual.  The room is illuminated by a single bare bulb hanging from the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (showing Hooker photographs of three men) These are Combs' favorite torpedoes. Riley and Cole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We recognize Riley and Cole as the two guys who got into Mottola's cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do most of the small jobs, but Lonnegan might not wanna use 'em on you 'cause they're kinda messy.  No class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Hooker.  He's real grateful.  Billie, wearing an evening dress, enters the room and begins gathering up th empty beer mugs on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got reason to believe Riley was the guy who hit Luther.  But if you see either one of these two, find yourself a crowd, or take 'em someplace you know you can handle 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But most of all let us know.  If they got a hit on you, we gotta fold up the con.  You're too exposed.  You got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker nods, but we know he hasn't really got that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it'll be one of these two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  They're just the only ones we know of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie has finished  gathering the mugs, and leaves the r with them.  We follow her down the hall and into the:

dialogues.speaker: RECEIVING ROOM OF HER BROTHEL
dialogues.text: Carousel music filters up from the arcade below.  The roo has a bar along one wall and the rest of the space is tak up by tables and couches.  It's a comfortable place, but opulent.  Some of the girls sit patiently on the couches, others play canasta at the tables.  Most of the men are a the bar, fortifying themselves for the task at hand.  Bil comes over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the bartender) Set me up five more beers, will ya Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Danny goes to fill the mugs, Billie's eyes fix on a ma at the end of the bar. We move to reveal Snyder, intently scanning the room, as he'd lost a dancing partner in the crush.  Not finding wh he wants, he comes down the bar to Billie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the owner here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flipping out his badge) Lieutenant Snyder.  Bunco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joliet badge, Snyder.  Don't cut much up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to ignore her remark) I'm lookin' for a guy on the lam from a counterfeiting rap.  Thought he mighta come in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think so.  I know everybody in the place and I always bounce the lamsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right if I look around your lobby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but you're welcome to a free beer before you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie grabs a bottle of beer, pours some in a shot glass and pushes it over to Snyder.  He ignores the gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with controlled force) I don't really need your permission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Billie.  She knew that when he came in.

dialogues.speaker: THE STORAGE ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: The discussion continues.  Hooker, a bit out of his depth here, listens and stays silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan's a fast egg, Henry.  He's not gonna sit still for a standard play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody'll sit still for somethin'. What did ya find out about the train, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been taking the 8:10 Century Limited outa New York on Friday and getting in here early Saturday morning.  He usually stays a day to check on his policy operations, and then flies back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonder why he doesn't fly both ways.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The porters say he runs a braced card game in one of the cars.  $100 minimum, straight poker.  Last time he pulled in here ten grand heavier than he left New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fancies himself a gambler, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lotta plungers ride that train just to play him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking into a smile) See J.J., he's slowly down already.

dialogues.speaker: THE RECEIVING ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Snyder has completed his inspection of the "lobby" and fo nothing.  Danny, meanwhile, has set up the five beers on tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which way are the rooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told ya this guy was in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.  I just know what kinda women he likes.  I'm gonna check all the joyhouses till I find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I could help ya if ya told me his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll keep that to myself. Which way are the rooms?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right through there.  But I wouldn't go in there if I were you. (picks up the tray)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snidely) What are ya gonna do, call the cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have to.  You'll be bustin' in on the Chief of Police just up the hall. (she exits with the drinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder is stopped cold.  He calls after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your nose clean, lady.  He can't spend all his time here.

dialogues.speaker: THE STORAGE ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Billie comes over to Gondorff and whispers in his ear, wh the others talk.  His eyes flick momentarily to Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we ought to play him on the Rag.  It's the tightest game we got, and it's not all over the papers yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good, J.J.  You're not gonna con stocks to a banker.  Lonnegan's too smart for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, con the payoff to a gambler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist is right.  It won't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff has nodded to Billie and now rejoins the conversation.  She serves the others beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll use the wire.  Never known a gambler who wouldn't like to beat the ponies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wire is ten years outa date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he won't know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll give him the hook on the train, and play him here.  You think I can get in that poker game, Eddie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is show up with some money and look like a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also gotta win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at Hooker.  There is a challenge in their book. Gondorff smiles broadly, then casually, to them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, any of you guys been passing off any green goods lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go around the table.  No reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie, if that Dick comes in again, stall him till I can get a look at him.  And let me pay ya for these beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  It's on the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling out a $5 bill) Naw, I want ya to have this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hitches up Billie's skirt, and puts the bill in her ga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at it till ya go to bed though or it'll turn to paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie smiles and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks halfway down the hall and stops.  She can't wai Lifting up her skirt, she finds that the five has indeed turned to paper.  As she breaks into laughter and continu on down the hall, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually little more than a service area between two apartment buildings.  Niles, Kid Twist, and a middle-aged black man, named Benny Garfield, enter the alley with an man and follow him down a stairwell to a subterranean basement.  A faded sign above the door says Stenner's Billiards.  We follow them inside to a:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An office comes off it at one end.  Judging from the fluorescent lights overhead and the scattered cue racks which still hang tenuously on the walls, the place, indee used to be a pool hall.  Niles and Garfield go all the wa to the back, while Twist stays near the front with the ol man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks all right.  It's big enough and off the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  This is kinda short notice.  I'm not sure we can get it all done by Saturday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to.  Gondorff's ridin' the mark in from New York on the Century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garfield thinks it over a little.  He's taking another lo at the place.  We go to Twist and the old man by the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it. (pointing through the door) You manage the building at the end of the alley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with pride) For fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need a room over there that faces this way.  How much a week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only rents by the month.  Two hundred and fifty for the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling out his wallet) This is the last time I expect to see you down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching the bills being counted into his hand) Never heard of the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go back to Niles and Garfield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been a while since I stocked a wire store.  Not many mobs playing that anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we need is the bookie setup for now.  We'll worry about the telegraph office later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I'll rent ya everything I got in the warehouse for two grand.  That'll give ya phones, cages, blackboards and ticker gear. You supply the guys to move 'em. If you want a counter and bar, that's another grand.  I don't know where the hell I'm gonna get 'em though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, you can do better than that. We ain't no heel grifters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want the stuff tomorrow or don't ya?  It's gonna take hours just to clean it up. (pause) Besides, Gondorff's still a hot item.  Where am I gonna be if he gets hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give us what ya can, Benny. We'll send a truck down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist has rejoined them by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Garfield) You wanna work flat rate or percentage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the mark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doyle Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flat rate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Doyle Lonnegan, accompanied by two bodyguards Floyd, making his way through the station.  He stops at a cigar counter to buy some cigarettes, and we reveal Gondo and Hooker sitting on their suitcases on the other side o the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes fixed on Lonnegan) Guy in the blue pinstripe and grey fedora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker looks and finally spots him in the crowd.  We go b to Lonnegan, as he moves off from the cigar counter, towa his train.  Hooker watches him with the intensity of one gazing on a religious object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not as tough as he'd like to think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up his suitcase) Neither are we.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan and his retainers getting on the train.  Two car down the line, we see Hooker and Gondorff boarding also. his way in, Gordorff takes the conductor aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear there's a friendly poker game on this train tonight.  You know anything about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could get me in that game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  There's usually a waiting list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff flashes a $50 bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loosening up a bit) That'll get you first alternate, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff pulls out another fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the money) I'll see what I can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid Twist enters and threads his way through the maze of tables to a door at the back of the building.  A large bu of a man is stationed there, obviously to discourage thos who don't have credentials to enter.  Twist is not such a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going right on through) How ya doin', Lacey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently pleased for one so menacing) Good to see ya again, Twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside is another room, this one much better lit than the outer one.  There are only three tables in here, around which are seated the elite of the Con World.  Twist is enthusiastically greeted by Duke Boudreau, a large, rotun man whose stylish dress and authoritative manner mark him a powerful figure in this group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist!  When did you get back in town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coupla days ago.  I'm workin' a big one with Gondorff on the North Side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men sit down together, apart from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen Duke, we're setting up a wire store.  I need a twenty man boost right away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got twenty or so in here tonight. Take your pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys have gotta be the quill, Duky.  We can't afford to rank the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one of his assistants) Get me the sheet, Jake.  Let's see who's in town.

dialogues.speaker: THE OUTER PART OF THE BAR AGAIN
dialogues.text: A silhouetted figure appears in the entrance doorway.  Th word "chill" races from table to table and the place fall still.  The bartender pushes a button behind the bar and buzzer goes off in the back room.  Boudreau gets up from table and opens a small viewing port in the door. The silhouetted figure is now walking slowly past the sil tables.  It's Snyder and he's checking out every face in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist, you know this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a look through the viewing port) No.  Never saw him before.  He's a dick, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder walks all the way to the back, and then retraces h route.  About halfway back, he stops at one of the tables recognizing a grifter he knows.  It's the Eirie Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Snyder.  What are you doin' up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on vacation.  You seen your friend lately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, he packed it in and enrolled in detective school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder, in no mood for jokes, grabs Eirie by the hair and slams his face into the table.  Eirie just stays there; h knows it doesn't pay to assault a detective.  Twist is watching all this intently from the viewing port.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see him, you tell him to pay his debts before I get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie raises his head slowly, but says nothing.  There is slight trickle of blood from his nose.  Snyder turns and walks slowly out of the bar.  When he is a safe distance down the street, the chatter and drinking resume.

dialogues.speaker: THE INSIDE ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Twist gives an all clear signal and returns to the table where he and Boudreau were talking.  Boudreau reads from list of names.  Twist listens with a certain preoccupatio He's still thinking about the little confrontation he jus witnessed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paltrow, Sterling, Furey, and the Big Alabama are in from New Orleans. Fiskin and the Boone Kid from Denver, and Phillips, Barnett and Limehouse Chappie from New York. Those and the guys outside should give ya 30 or so to choose from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, have 'em down at Stenner's old Pool Hall before 3:00.  We're gonna run through the route tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Twist, but you know if this blows up, I can't do ya no good downtown.  Gondorff is Federal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ripping through an open stretch between New York and Chic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singleton is walking down a passageway and stops at a doo and goes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff is rapidly shuffling cards to four empty places. He is alone.  He looks up as Singleton enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, I think so.  I gave the kay- ducer a C-note.  You find out the deck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He usually plays with a Royal or a Cadenza. (handing him two sealed decks) I got you one of each.  He likes to cold deck low, 8's or 9's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice work, J.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singleton slips out as Gondorff unpeels the packs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Lonnegan coming out of his compartment, flanke by only one bodyguard and Floyd.  He starts through the passenger section toward the compartment where the poker game will be held.  Suddenly a drunken woman comes stagge around the corner and bumps into him. They grapple a moment and Lonnegan pushes her away in dis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sloppy drunk) Keep your mitts off me, ya big lug. If I'da wanted you handlin' me I woulda asked ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan ignores her and proceeds down the passageway.  A the woman proceeds in the other direction between passeng we see it is Billie.  She drops something on a seat besid passenger.  A hand reaches to pick it up.  It is Lonnegan wallet and it is Hooker who picks it up. Hooker waits a moment, then stands and goes in the direct Lonnegan has taken.  He passes by the open door to the ca room, hesitating only slightly to hear the greetings exchanged inside before the door is shut.  Then he contin on into the next car.  He turns into Gondorff's compartme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff is still practicing.  He looks up as Hooker ente and tosses him the wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got him clean.  He hasn't missed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff nods, takes the money out, counts it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen grand.  Looks like he's expecting a big night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out his own wallet and puts the money in it, and tosses the empty wallet back to Hooker, and resumes his shuffling and dealing.  Hooker sits back silently and watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waitin' for you in the card room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let him wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he deals, on the second pass he attempts to cut from t bottom, muffs it completely and sprays half the deck on t table.  Hooker regards him steadily as he gathers them ba up.  Gondorff finally meets his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just worry about your end, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we ever get to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A specially outfitted compartment with a table and chairs the middle and leather cushions around the outside for kibitzers.  Lonnegan and 3 other players are already ther and seated.  They're getting slightly impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Conductor) Where the hell is this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  He said he'd be here.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF'S CABIN AGAIN
dialogues.text: Gondorff is standing in front of the mirror dressing.  He grabs up a clean white shirt and rumples it up in his han He then picks up a half-full bottle of bourbon.  Hooker gives him a disapproving look.  Gondorff smiles and pats some on his face.

dialogues.speaker: THE POKER ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Everybody's itchy now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, let's start without him. Mr. Clemens, give me the cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Conductor hands him a sealed deck.  As he begins to o it, Gordoff comes into the room, coatless, rumpled, unsha and looking slightly tipsy.  The others at the table, all men of high school or financial standing, are somewhat pu off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late boys.  I was takin' a crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This bit of grossness does little to improve his image.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making the introductions; referring first to Gondorff) Mr. Shaw is a bookmaker from Chicago.  Mr. Shaw, meet Mr. Clayton from Pittsburgh, Mr. Jameson, Chicago, Mr. Lonnegan, New York and Mr. Lombard, Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff nods and takes a seat, none too gracefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straight poker, gentlemen.  100 dollar minimum, table stakes.  We assume you're good for your debts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuffling the cards) Mr. Shaw, we usually require a tie at this table.  If you don't have one, we can get ya one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, that'd be real nice of ya, Mr. Lonneman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begins to deal, obviously not pleased that his evening seems to be peopled with drunks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck is now parked at the end of the alley, and severa workmen are busy unloading it.  One group carries a large blackboard; others have boxes of glasses, ash tray stands furniture, etc.  Take several cuts.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE ONCE-VACANT POOL HALL
dialogues.text: Now a blaze of activity.  We take several cuts of workmen papering the walls, tacking down carpet, putting in new light fixtures, painting signs, all under the supervision Niles.
