From now on, we will refer to the pool hall as th store. Back in the office, Kid Twist is "interviewing" one by on a group of con men lined up outside the office door.  A gray-haired old buzzard, Curly Jackson, approaches the ta which is serving Twist as a desk.  Curly is practically i rags and has several days growth on his face.  He wears a little beret which he takes off to address Twist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Curly Jackson.  I worked for Gad Bryan outa Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever played the Wire, Curly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to rope for it long ago.  I can shill, mark board, anything you want.  I don't run with riffraff and I only drink on weekends. (affecting an English accent) Me specialty is an Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist is taken with the man, despite his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Curly, you're in.  We got a rack of suits over there. Get yourself a nice tweed one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exiting) That's all right.  I got all my own stuff.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARD GAME AGAIN
dialogues.text: Gondorff and Lonnegan have most of the chips.  Lonnegan i slightly ahead.  Gondorff has made a token attempt to wea the provided tie, having tied it in a knot around his nec but not having bothered to put it under his collar.  He h a shot glass and a bottle next to him, from which he has been drinking heavily.  He and Lonnegan are the only ones left in this hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing chips in) Raise 500.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (likewise) See ya and raise three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more chips) See and raise five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five and call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan lays down his hand, a solid two pair.  Gondoroff turns out three tens.  Lonnegan is beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough luck, Lonnihan, but that's what you get for playin' with your head up your ass.  Couple more like that and we can all go to bed early, huh boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan burns, and the "boys" have no comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The work is still progressing.  We see two workmen instal a ticket tape machine in a secluded area of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We bought ya a tap into Moe Anenberg's wire.  He's got eyes at every track in the country.  You'll get race results, odds, scratches, pole positions, everything; and just as fast as Western Union gets 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does J.J. know how to use this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he's gotta do is read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Kid Twist, still conducting interviews in the office.  A young, rather sullen man, Buck Duff, steps to table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck Duff.  I was in Maxwell's boost in Troy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You the Duff that didn't come up with his end when Little Jeff was sent up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't no problem a mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a con man, wasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a tear-off rat.  He got what he deserved.  No sense helpin' pay his bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like ice) Shove off, Duff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duff stands there a second and then slouches away from th table.  He stops however, by the door.  The next man up i the Eirie Kid.  Twist knows he's seen him somewhere befor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous as hell) Names's Joe Eirie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist waits for more, but it's not coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You played for any particular mobs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the Wire at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...I never played no Big Con before.  But Luther Coleman was a friend a mine.  I thought maybe there was something I could do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to Eirie slightly swollen nose) You get that nose in Duke Boudreau's tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie nods a reluctant "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got moxie, Eirie.  Get yourself a suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie is so happy, he can barely blurt out a thank you. Buck Duff, enraged that Twist would hire a total amateur, turns in disgust and strides vengefully out of the store.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARD GAME AGAIN
dialogues.text: The room is dense with smoke now, and the players are feeling the heat.  Gondorff has his white shirt open, revealing a stained T-shirt underneath.  The bottle next him is almost empty.  He sneezes and wipes his nose with tie Lonnegan gave him. The chips are now about equally divided between Gondorff Lonnegan.  The others are losing badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise 300.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throwing in his last few chips) Raise 200.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two and call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jameson lays down two pair.  Gondorff has a flush.  Gondo rakes in the chips, which now put him ahead of Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, pal.  Lemongan here wouldn'ta let you in the game if you weren't a chump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to his feet) I've had enough of your lip, Shaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff grabs the whiskey bottle next to him, breaks it against the table and waves the jagged end in Lonnegan's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely able to stand up) Just take it easy there, Larrabee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jameson and the conductor step in between.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a break for a couple minutes and cool off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan storms out of the room, followed by Floyd and Bodyguard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Lonnegan coming down the passageway to enter t smoking room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his assistant) I've had it with that bum, Floyd. Stack me a cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to settle him down) You've only been playin three hours, Doyle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not to be pacified) I don't care.  Load me a deck.  Set it up for threes and nines.  I'll cut it in on his deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a deck and beginning to sort it) What do ya want the others to get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'.  They gotta be outa there early.  I'm gonna bust that bastard in one play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of hands shuffling.  We pull back to reveal that they're Gondorff's.  He passes the deck to Lonnegan to be cut and turns to pen a new whiskey bottle.  Lonnegan take the deck and in one lightning motion substitutes a new de while making it look like he's cutting the old one. Gondorff picks up the deck and begins to deal.  As the ha is picked up, we see that Gondorff has four threes, Lonne four nines, and everybody else has nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening the bidding) Fold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise 1,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise 500.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff looks at Lonnegan very carefully for a second. Lonnegan meets his stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Raise 2,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spectators shift a little.  It's the biggest bet of t night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See and raise 1,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it to him) Raise 5,000.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan fingers his remaining chips.  He knows he's won, but he wants to bleed it for every bit of suspense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (going for broke) See, and raise the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan pushes in the rest of his chips.  Gondorff, who only required to match Lonnegan's total, throws in all hi too.  It's a showdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan puts down his four nines.  Gondorff just stares them a second, lets out a deep sigh and lays down four ja Lonnegan is aghast.  This just can't be.  He glances at Floyd, who can do nothing but sit there with his mouth op

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raking in the chips) Well that's all for me tonight, boys.  I'm gonna leave ya some cab fare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other players look at each other in disgust, and reac for their wallets, all of which are well stocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Lonnegan) You owe me 15 grand, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan, with a stare that could kill, reaches for his wallet.  Suddenly the stare goes soft.  He tries a few mo pockets.  No soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up to get it) I guess I left it in my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blowing up) What!  Don't give me that crap you little weenie.  How do I know you ain't gonna take a powder. (waving his wallter, which is full of Lonnegan's money) You come to a game like this, you bring your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan, having had all he can take, goes for Gondorff, is restrained by the conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, buddy, I'm gonna send a boy by your room in five minutes, and you better have that jack, or it's gonna be all over Chicago that your name ain't worth a dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff stalks out of the room.  We pick him up coming d the passageway to his compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drunkenness has vanished.  We follow him into his cab where Hooker is waiting anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd ya do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (modestly) Well we got some workin' money anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff tosses his winnings on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile) Okay, kid, you're on.  But I gotta tell ya, its a hard act to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan sits in a chair smoking, obviously still upset. Floyd paces in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I give him four threes.  We can't let him get away with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I supposed to do?  Call him for cheating better than me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock at the door.  Floyd goes and opens it.  I Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Carver.  Mr. Shaw sent me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Floyd motions him in without a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your boss is quite a card player, Carver.  How does he do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very matter-of-factly) He cheats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan says nothing.  He doesn't like smart asses.  He looks Hooker over a second, as if considering whether to have him wasted or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching into his coat pocket) He'll have to take a check. (pulling out a check) I couldn't find my wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, he knows that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling out Lonnegan's wallet and tossing it to him) He hired a dame to take it from ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan just holds the wallet.  He can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were set up, Lonnegan.  Shaw's been planning to beat your game for months.  He was just waiting for you to cheat him so he could clip ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the heat rising) I could have you put under this train for this, errand boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool as hell) So could Shaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why the rat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause I'm tired of bein' his nigger. (pause) I want you to help me break him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan looks at Hooker long and hard, as if the intensi of his gaze could separate truth from fiction.  Lonnegan hadn't expected this, but now that it's here, it better b on the level.  The silence is suddenly broken by the nois of the train braking into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Hooker) C'mon, I'll give ya a lift home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker hesitates, not sure whether to accept or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?  You gotta get back to Shaw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, he picked up some jane in the bar.  Can't see him till morning anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving through the city, the driver and Floyd in front, Hooker and Lonnegan in back. Hooker glances out the window from time to time, just to make sure they're really going to his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me?  Shaw probably has lotsa enemies to choose from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need somebody respectable...but not completely legit.  What I'm gonna do isn't very legal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insulted) I'm a banker, friend.  That's legit in this state.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you gotta do is place a bet for me at Shaw's place.  I'll supply all the money and the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is listening, but you'd never know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you help me out, I'll pay ya back the money you owe Shaw, myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's worth fifteen grand to ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a couple million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Lonnegan.  He's still not talking, but that last phrase has registered.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOOKER'S PLACE
dialogues.text: The car pulls up in front of Hooker's place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dreamin', kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting out) 660 Marshall Street.  Tomorrow at 12:30, if you're interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (diffidently) If I'm not there by quarter of, I'm not coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker nods and walks up the steps to his apartment build Lonnegan's car speeds away from the curb and on out of si Hooker breathes a sigh of relief.  He's passed his first test; or has he?  We follow him up the stairs to his room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just about to unlock the door, when he notices the little piece of paper he left in the door is on the floor Without the slightest hesitation, Hooker leaps over the bannister and races back down the stairs.  Two gunmen, Ri and Cole, burst out of his room and fire at him over the railing, but he's already too far down.  Riley and Cole g chase.

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT OF THE BUILDING
dialogues.text: Riley and Cole barrel out of the building and onto the sidewalk.  There is an empty bus stopped at a light, but they find no sign of Hooker.  As the light changes, we cu to the other side of the bus, where we see Hooker crouche on the rear wheel housing, hanging on to a vent.  He's a little shaken, but most of all, he's still alive.  We hol on him, as the bus moves off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything go all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying) Yeh, it was easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Gondorff are sitting alone in the back office while the work goes on outside.  Their conversation conti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No signs of trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do ya mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, somebody tailin' ya.  A torpedo or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wanting to get off the subject) No, not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff has his doubts, but lets them ride.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER PARTS OF THE STORE
dialogues.text: We concentrate on some of the fine details, i.e. Garfield explaining how the ticker will read out to Singleton and Billie; Curly Jackson showing a younger con man how to ma the odds board properly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout Lonnegan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him the breakdown just like ya told me to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He threatened to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, they don't do that and you know you're not gettin' through to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We concentrate on Niles, who's making up the "boodles" or fake bankrollls.  He puts a real $100 bill on the bottom, then two inches of cut green paper on top, and then anoth $100 bill on top of that, so that it looks like he has a whole stack of $100 bills.  The bundle is then bound with sealed label, like those used in banks, that says $10,000 We see that he has already made several of these bundles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he drove me home.  He tried to put himself away as legit, so I went right into the pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he hold you up on anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, he just sat there and listened. I don't know if he bought it or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist in the middle of the room giving a route to the Eir Kid.  He shows him where to get his drink at the bar, whe to sit and finally how to leap up and throw his racing fo down in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.  Once they start listening, they're in trouble. Just don't give him more than he asks for.  If you rattle his imagination a little, he'll come up with all the right answers himself. But all he's gotta do is catch you in one lie and you're dead.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER AND GONDORFF IN THE STORE OFFICE AGAIN
dialogues.text: They both look tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think he'll show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he say he wouldn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) He'll show.

dialogues.speaker: THE ALLEY OUTSIDE THE STORE
dialogues.text: At first it appears to be deserted, but we move to reveal figure in an upper window of the apartment building which forms one side of the alley.  It's Kid Twist.  His eyes r the street, for what, we do not yet know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably prosperous at one time, it has since declined, i large fountain and eating area bow host to two bums and Hooker, who sits alone in a rear booth near the telephone Dressed in a tuxedo, he nurses a cup of coffee, and anxio alternates his glances between the clock and the empty street outside.  It's 12:52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is full of people, although we avoid long shot as not to give away the room as a whole yet.  Instead, we concentrate on the tense, waiting faces of some of the mo familiar people: Gondorff and Niles in tuxedos behind a barred cashier's a Gondorff mutilates a piece of gum in his mouth.  Niles ju stares out into space cracking his knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, cut that out, will ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boardmarker walking nervously back and forth in front his odds board, checking every letter and number.  He sto to cross a T on one of the horses' names.  It was already crossed, but he does it again anyway. Billie and Singleton, in an area hidden from the rest of room, watching the print-out on the ticker machine.  The clicking of the ticker is the only sound we hear in the s Curly Jackson in front of a mirror, pasting a fake Van Dy on his chin to go with his tweed suit and monocle. A couple of Billie's girls adjusting their waitress outfi and primping their hair.  Each has a tray full of drinks beside her. The Eirie Kid silently retracing his "route" to make sure has it down. Despite the crowd, there is no talking and little movemen save for the constant swirling of smoke from several ciga and cigarettes.  The group is like a theatre company wait to go on opening night.

dialogues.speaker: THE DRUGSTORE AGAIN
dialogues.text: It's 12:56 and Hooker is worried.  He looks up to see two large men, obviously racket goons, come in the front door and take a seat facing him in the next booth.  They stare him impassively, waving the waitress away when she comes take their order.  Hooker knows they're Lonnegan's men, b is somewhat unsettled by the fact that Lonnegan is not wi them.  Suddenly, a voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker turns around to find that Lonnegan is seated in th booth directly behind him.  His bodyguard is in the one behind that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should always look to the back too, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sliding out of his booth and into Lonnegan's) I was afraid you weren't gonna come. We haven't got much time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly) Get on with it then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to telephone) Sometime after 1:00 a guy's gonna call here and give you the name of a horse. (pulling out a wad of bills) All you do is take this two grand across the street to Shaw's place and bet it on that pony.  There's nothin' to it, but don't take too much time.  We only have 3 or 4 minutes after you get the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna break him with a $2,000 bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is just a test.  The big one comes later.  Be careful with that though, it's all I got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you were gonna pay me back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am after this race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan says nothing.  He's not sure he likes a man who' stupid enough to bet his last dollar on a horse race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get back before Shaw misses me.  Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker hustles out across the street and into the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan watches him through the window and then settles back in his seat to wait for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE STORE
dialogues.text: As Hooker descends the stairwell into the store, he gives Kid Twist the office.  Twist turns away from the window a looks at his watch.  12:58.

dialogues.speaker: DRUGSTORE
dialogues.text: Lonnegan waiting by the phone, idly pinging a knife on th salt shaker.  It's 1:40.  A man enters the store and walk over to use the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're waitin' for a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man looks at Lonnegan a second, and then at his four goons.  He decides maybe he'll make the call later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid Twist again.  Billie enters the room with a piece of paper.  Kid Twist looks at it a second and then picks up pohne and begins to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan again.  He's getting impatient now and lights a cigarette, and then the phone rings.  He answers it quick and we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluenote at 6 to 1 on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The receiver clicks down at the other end.  Lonnegan hang up and goes out the door, followed by his entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow him across the street and into the alley, where signals one of the bodyguards to check the place out.  Ki Twist pushes a button on his window sill, and a buzzer go off inside the store.  The previously inert figures there spring to life. Lonnegan's bodyguard descends the stairwell and knocks at the door, where he is greeted by Hooker in the capacity o host.  He looks the place over and motions an okay to Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lonnegan enters, we see the room for the first time in its entirety.  Overnight it has been transformed into a swank private club, with bar, cigarette girls, upholstere furniture and chandeliers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that.  He's got four apes with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I like about these guys, J.J... They always got protection against things we'd never do to 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere there is activity.  A bank of telephones buzze incessantly.  Sheet writers scurry from phone to phone, taking bets of tremendous size from prominent people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Ruth, 20,000 on Dancing Cloud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We reveal that the phones are controlled by a master swit which one of the recruited con men operates from behind a partition. The boardmaker, wearing headphones suspended from a slidi wire, hurriedly chalks up races and odds on a huge blackb From the loudspeakers we hear the words "last flash." The odds on Bluenote settle down to 8 to 1. Lonnegan makes his way through the throng toward the bett line.  His bodyguards fan out to various positions in the room.  The betting crowd itself (known as the "boost") consists of close to twenty people, none of whom, of cour are what they're pretending to be.  There are brokers wit pasty faces, sportsmen, tanned and casual, and financiers with goatees and highly tailored clothes.  Large amounts money are changing hands at the betting window.  Boodles in sight everywhere. Lonnegan slips into the betting line, feeling somewhat estranged from the general merriment around him.  There a two men in line ahead of him.  The first, Curly Jackson, slaps down several bundles of cash in front of Niles, who the cashier, and places a $20,000 bet on War Eagle.  Gond appears at the cashier's window and catches sight of Lonn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never get enough, huh pal?  I'd think you'd get tired of losin', Honnigan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (piercingly) The name is Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Niles) Make sure you see cash from this guy, Eddie.  He's got the name for bettin' money he don't have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man in front of Lonnegan puts $5,000 on Dancing Cloud He makes the bet on credit.  Lonnegan steps to the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-thousand on Bluenote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (writing out a ticket) Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed) That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bluenote's race is now up on the board.  The race caller comes on the loudspeaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen.  This is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the second race at Belmont in New York. A mile and 1/8.  Four year olds and up.  And they're off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that the caller is Singleton, and that he's callin the race from a concealed booth next to the cashier's cag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the first turn it's a War Eagle first by a length, Jail Bate second by one and a half, Dancing Cloud third by a half on the outside, followed by Lucky Lady, Mojo, Wits' End and Bluenote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan goes to the bar, orders a drink, and settles dow at one of the tables.  It happens to be the one the Eirie Kid is at.  Gondorff and Niles watch it from the cashier' cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worried) That's not where we want him to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie tries to ignore Lonnegan at first, but realizes he better make some conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon War Eagle. (to Lonnegan) That Dancing Cloud's a hell of a finisher.  War Eagle's gonna have to open up a little more on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know anything about a horse named Bluenote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, he's never done much.  Probably in here just to round out the field. War Eagle's where you wanna have your money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie excuses himself and heads for the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the clubhouse turn, it's War Eagle by two lengths, Dancing Cloud has moved up to second by a half, Lucky Lady is third by three followed by Jail Bait, Mojo, Bluenote and Wits' End.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The heretofore chaotic energy of the parlor is now focuse on the race.  Several of the patrons begin to yell for th horses.  Lonnegan remains seated.  He seems bored with it all.  Hooker comes over to clear some empty glasses from table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of the corner of his mouth) You really picked a winner, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em a little time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the backstretch it's War Eagle still by a length, Dancing Cloud closing on the inside, is second by two, Lucky Lady is third by one and a half, followed by Bluenote, Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan perks up just a little.  Bluenote, at least, has moved up.  The rest of the people in the place are really rooting now.  Few of them remain seated. Hooker arrives at the bar, with the glasses he cleared fr Lonnegan's table.  Eirie is already there, fortifying himself with a scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doin' great, Eirie.  He loves ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie nods, somewhat unconvinced, and heads bak to the ta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Into the far turn, it's Dancing Cloud now by half a length, War Eagle is second by two, Bluenote is third by a half and moving fast on the outside.  Lucky Lady is fourth by four lengths, followed by Jail Bait, Wits' End and Mojo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is getting more intent now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming down the stretch, it's Dancing Cloud by one length, War Eagle and Bluenote are neck and neck by two.  Now it's Dancing Cloud, Bluenote and War Eagle. (shouting now) Dancing Cloud and Bluenote head to head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is going crazy.  Even Singleton is standing up get the necessary excitement in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  Dancing Cloud, Bluenote.  It's Bluenote by a nose.  Dancing Cloud is second by two, War Eagle third by three and a half.  Time for a mile and 1/8, 2:01 and 6/10 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the patrons collapse into their chairs like spent lovers.  Eirie slams his racing form to the floor.  Nobod had Bluenote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tearing up his ticket) Bloody awful.  Who in blazes is Bluenote?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Eirie, very self-satisfied) War Eagle's where you want to have your money, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie doesn't reply.  He can't believe Bluenote won. Lonnegan looks to Hooker.  Hooker gives him a wink.  For the first time, Lonnegan permits a smile.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN AT THE CASHIER'S WINDOW
dialogues.text: Niles is counting out $16,000 to him (all of which Gondor won the night before).  Gondorff looks somewhat perturbed Lonnegan picks up the money and tauntingly waves it at hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting his name right this time) Don't bother to come back with a piker's bet like that again, Lonnegan.  We got a $5,000 minimum here. (to Hooker) Show this bum out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker hesitates a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, ya goddamn ninny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff gives Hooker a hard shove in the back with his foot, sending him into a table and sprawling to the floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating Lonnegan's bodyguards) And tell him not to bring his garbage men in here no more.  This is a class joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker, pretending to be humiliated, gets to his feet and escorts Lonnegan to the door.  Lonnegan stops, gives Gond a derisive smile, and walks out.  Once he's gone, the general clatter and hubbub in the room cease, like it had been turned off by a faucet.  Most of the boost sit down relax.  Curly Jackson rips off his Van Dyke.  It's been itching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gaffed, kid.  He should start coming to you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs sits passively on the edge of his desk glancing acr the room every now and then at Riley, who is slumped unea in a folding chair, looking like a defendant at the Inquisition.  Both remain silent, like two men in a waiti room.  Suddenly, what they've been waiting for arrives. Lonnegan comes into the office, flanked by his bodyguards Skipping the usual pleasantries, he walks right over to R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Riley.  What the hell happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking at him) We missed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't hired to miss him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There wasn't any way he coulda known we was in there.  We made a clean pick on the lock and didn't leave no footprints in the hall. Somebody musta wised him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, and what does Cole say about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  He took it hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, get outa here.  You're outta work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Riley gets up and drags himself out the door like a whipp dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll put Salino on it.  I need somebody careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salino?  Why waste our best people on a small-time job like this?  It ain't no heavy gee we're after. The guy's a five and dime grifter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why ain't he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't think he'd be so cagey, that's all.  They'll get him next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use Salino.  It'll take a little longer, but there won't be any holes in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs gives up.  The second time's the charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And tell Cole I wanta see him when he gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not comin' in.  Not to get bounced off a job anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had his chance and all he did was shoot up a rooming house.  Made a lotte noise and woke up a few cops, but didn't hit nothin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combs keeps his mouth shut.  There's no way to talk to Lonnegan when  he's like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cooling a little) This is Salino's job now, Vince. If Cole wants to muscle in on it, that's his business.  But he's breakin' the rules and when Salino finds out about it, I can't feel sorry for what's gonna happen to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The finest the period had to offer.  We pick up Hooker coming down the hall to Lonnegan's suite.  He is admitted the Bodyguard.  Lonnegan, wearing a smoking jacket, is seated at a table counting a pile of money.  There are tw other assistants standing behind him.  They don't look friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what did I tell ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lucky man, all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky, hell.  I could do it every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't ya then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause it's better to do it all at once. (leaning close) We're puttin' down 400 grand next week.  At 5-1 we make 2 million. Twenty per cent of that is yours if ya stick with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a system, Carver?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stayin' in or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drawing up a chair, barely able to contain his enthusiasm) It's foolproof.  We got a partner downtown runs the central office of the Western Union.  Race results from all over the country come in there and go right across his desk on their way to the bookies.  All he does in hold them up a couple minutes until he can call us and get a bet down on the winner.  Then he releases the results to the bookies and we clean up on a race that's already been run.  It can't miss, unless the Western Union Dicks get onto it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is amazed.  He sits back a second, then comes forward again and pushes a pile of bills over to Hooker. Hooker smiles and begins to count the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the 400 grand yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet, but... (stopping suddenly) Hey, there's only a grand here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more like a command) I think we oughta place another bet tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting angry) What is this?  That's my money. You tryin' to muscle me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (controlled) If your system's as foolproof as you say, you'll get even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's in a jam and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I gotta talk to me partner first. We can't afford to expose our game too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want your money back?  Try and get it in a court of law. (softening a bit) C'mon, don't be a sorehead.  I'll make it worth your while.  Migth even help ya finance the big play if this one works out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker says nothing for a minute, and then reluctantly no his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four o'clock tomorrow.  Pick me up at Dewey Lyle's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Hooker coming out of the hotel and going off d the street.  As he does so, we pull back all the way acro the street and through the interior of a parked car to reveal the silhouette of a man seated at the wheel.  We m to his right hand, which rests on the steering column.  I covered by a black glove and the middle finger is missing His trigger finger, however, taps lightly on the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the old, wooden kind -- accordian doors with glass panes in the upper half.  Hooker dials rapidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist?  I told him the tale.  He wants to see ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, after 4:00.  Stay inside, I'll come in and get ya.  And be hard on him for a while; he's talking money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Tootsie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker blows a mock kiss through the phone and hangs up. turns to leave the booth, when suddenly he sees something that stops him cold.  There looking through the glass is smirking face of Detective Synder.  Hooker is immobilized Snyder puts his hand inside his coat and slowly draws out his gun.  He points it right at Hooker's face and then violently smashes all the glass in the upper half of the door with the barrel.  Fragments of glass spray into the booth, a couple of which imbed themselves in Hooker's che Hooker quickly whips open the door, trapping Snyder's han in the accordian and jarring loose his gun.  Hooker sprin out of the booth as Snyder scrambles for his pistol and gives pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow the two men up alleys and sidestreets as they r through the dregs of the city, two panting shadows moving through places that only get light at night.  The wind bl drops of blood off Hooker's cheek as he runs.  Snyder sti has his gun, but would rather inflict pain than death.

dialogues.speaker: CONDEMNED BUILDING
dialogues.text: Hooker makes for a condemned building and scrambles up th stairs, steps giving way under him as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the fourth floor, he ducks into a room and quickly loc the door. We pan the room to reveal that the whole back side of the building is gone.  Hooker runs toward the ledge and leaps through the air, landing on the fire escape of an adjacen building, some 15 feet away.  He kicks in a window and go off down the hall.  We cut back to Snyder furiously kicking in the locked door.  He finally crashes through, only to find an empty room and a beautif panorama of the city and its nearest Hooverville.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Winding his way through the slum area of town, dashing al backstreets, over fences and through vacant lots, making good his escape.  From our angle, he looks like a rat in maze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me about Snyder before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker sits sullenly at the table.  Billie stands over hi putting some ointment on his face to close the cuts. Gondorff looks on.  Their discussion continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you found him again and we're gonna have to do somethin' about it. What else haven't ya been tellin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'.  I told ya everything there is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why'd ya move outa your room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was too noisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't play your friends like marks, Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker doesn't reply.  He knows Gondorff's on to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how easy it'd be for one of Lonnegan's guys to nail you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we need is a couple days, Henry. A couple days and we'll get Lonnegan down and stomp on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just won't learn, will ya. Hell, you come in here, I teach you stuff maybe five guys in this world know, stuff most grifters couldn't do even if they knew it, and all you wanna do is run down a bullet. (pause) You're just like all them new jerks. Lotsa nerve and no brains.  And ten years from now when me and the others are through and you dumb guys are all dead there won't be one gee left who knows the Big Con was anything more than a way to make a livin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple days; that's all I'm askin'.  I can stay clear that long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be angry and failing) Christ, they'll probably miss you and hit me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Located across the street from Hooker's apartment buildin Hooker sits down alone in a booth, with a plate of ham an eggs he's hardly touched. The two cuts on his face have pretty much stopped bleedin A big fan above the counter area drones away lethargicall it's air stream insufficient to either cool the place or drive out the smell of onions and grease. A waitress, Loretta, emerges from the kitchen and ambles slowly over to Hooker's table.  Slim and raven-haired, sh manifests an indifference bred from years spent deliverin things to people who are rarely grateful for what she bri Only a light scar on her left cheek hints at another side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, I guess I shoulda had the meat loaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) It isn't any better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's June today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (figuring up the bill) She don't work here no more.  I'm fillin' in for a couple days... till I can get a train outa here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting the check down and walking away) I don't know.  Depends what train I get on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker looks for some sign that she's putting him on.  He doesn't get it.  He takes out some money, drops it on the table and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck with the words CLAYTON BROS., CUSTOM PAINTING AND DECORATING stenciled on the side, is parked out front.  T men, wearing overalls and painter's caps, walk into the office to the reception counter, we see that they are Twi and Singleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the receptionist) Excuse me.  We're here to paint Mr. Harmon's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obviously not expecting them) Mr. Harmon's office?  Hold on just a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to get Mr. Harmon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is standing on the curb outside the diner, obvious waiting for somebody.  Lonnegan's car pulls up and Hooker hops in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to your face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had a little fight with a raggle down on 13th.  She got me with her ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Harmon is looking over the authorization papers that Twist and Singleton have given him.  He can't find anythi wrong with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brigham signed it all right.  I can't understand why he didn't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, he's like all them supervisors. They think they're too good for regular people.  He says he was in here a while ago and the place was a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harmon looks around, hoping it's not true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll try and hurry so we don't keep you out of your office too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't I work with you in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look pal, we gotta cover the floor, the furniture, everything, so we don't spill on nothing.  Now if you wanta sit in there with a tarp over your head, you're welcome to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, how long will you be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hour or two at the most.  We do good work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harmon is resigned.  Twist and Singleton pick up their ge and march into the office.  Once inside, we notice that t office has an exit door which opens to an outside alley. Twist immediately removes his overalls, revealing the sui and tie he's wearing underneath.  He takes out a picture himself, a woman and three small children, and puts it on Harmon's desk, replacing a similiar picture of Harmon's family.  Singleton, meanwhile, has spread a few tarps and begins to paint the walls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan's car pulls up and stops across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go to the side door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Hooker and Lonnegan across the street to the si entrance which opens into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker knocks and Twist, of course, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Les, I got Mr. Lonnegan with me. He wants to see you a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated) What the hell's the matter with you. We coulda met at a club or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it might be good for him to see the setup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hushed) Well we can't talk in here.  They're having the place painted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist walks over to the intercom on his desk.  He leaves door open so that Lonnegan can get a good look at the office, Twist's picture in it, the painter, etc... Lonneg not missing any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (talking into the intercom) Miss Barnes, I'm going home a little early today.  Tell anyone that calls that they can reach me here in the morning.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harmon's secretary at the other end of the intercom.  Mr. Harmon is with her.  They look at each other a second and Harmon decides he better see what's happening in his offi He opens the door to find it empty except for a pile of painting equipment and one haphazardly painted wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and somewhat foreboding, its peeling dragons and sho lanterns compete for space with the many slot machines an arcade games that line the walls.  Hooker, Lonnegan and Twist sit at one of the more secluded tables.  They are n eating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't do it.  There're telegraph inspectors all over the place.  I got 750 grand coming in from the coast, and I'm not gonna blow it for a lousy 14 gees.  We'll get somebody else to do our betting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could come up with 750 grand in a day if I had a reason to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But who says you will.  I got a guy I can depend on.  He's liquidating everything he has for this.  You wouldn't even give Carver his money back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need more proof, that's all. Anybody can get lucky once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stubbornly) On a 6-1 shot?  The hell with ya. We'll keep the deal we got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it works again tomorrow, I'll have a half million in cash here by noon the next day.  We split 60-40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feebly, beginning to break) We were getting 50 from our guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With 20% coming off the top for me laying your bet.  Either way you end up with 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week's a long time, friend. Anything can happen.  All of it bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Les.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, and what if we play tomorrow and he doesn't come up with the money.  We risk our whole operation for nothing.  I'll say when we make our bets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you want me to keep makin' 'em for ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do we know about your guy. He says a week, but who knows if it's a month?  Lonnegan here's a banker.  He can get that dough with no questions asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twist says nothing for a minute, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.  Be at the booth at 1:00. I'll give you all three places this time, Lonnegan.  That better be proof enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Lonnegan smile at each other like life-long friends.  They get up to leave, and we frame the shot wit coffee cup large in the foreground.  As they go out the door, a black-gloved hand with four fingers enters the fr and puts a nickel down next to the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder finishes a donut and a cup of coffee, puts down a dime for the lot and exits.  We follow him down the stree

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a corner newsstand, where he stops to buy a morning pa As he peruses it, he's approached by two large, clean-cut men in white skimmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Lieutenant William Snyder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F.B.I... The Captain'd like a few words with ya.  Ya got a couple minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely floored) Yeh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men show him to a waiting car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder stands in the middle of a dusty old machine room, surrounded by four or five Federal Agents.  Visible aroun the room are several folding cots and portable lockers. agents have obviously been quartered here temporarily.  T all wear white skimmers, save for one, a portly man, Capt Polk, who paces the room smoking.  There is something lon suffering about him, as if he wondered how he ever got in service that thought white skimmers were classy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this?  I got work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down and shut up, will ya.  Try not to live up to all my expectations. (not in the mood to screw around) We were told you know a hustle artist named Johnny Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do ya know him or don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, but I don't know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we do.  He's chummin' around with a Big C named Henry Gondorff. Ring any bells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Every bunco man in the country knows Gondorff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's word he's gonna run a con on the North Side here.  We got a year-old Florida warrant on him, but it's a thin beef, and he can beat it in court unless we catch him cold.  All we want you to do is pick up Hooker for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you pick him up yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cause the stoolies are used to street dicks jumpin' him.  If word gets around that Feds are in on it too, Gondorff'll fold up the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't that be too bad.  You'd hafta move outa this nice office ya got.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged) Don't crack wise to me, flatfoot. I spent a lotta time in dumps like this, eatin' Gondorff's dust while the bunco squad gets rich tippin' him off.  But it's not gonna happen this time.  We're not even gonna let the police know we're here.  If you keep your mouth shut and do a job, there'll be a promotion in it for ya.  And you better take it, cause I can make ya work for us without it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell good is Hooker to ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna set up Gondorff for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll never do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (self-satisfied) I think he will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan sits by the phone, watching the clock and sippin cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Specifically, the small room from which Singleton does hi race broadcasts.  Singleton, himself, is hunched over the ticker machine, reading the print-out.  Billie sits at th microphone table with a pencil and pad, ready to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visitation is still up by two at the three-quarters.  Single Action second, Fasanella third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the line on Visitation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking further up on the print-out sheet) 7 to 2.  That ain't bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll probably fall down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff appears at the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still glued to the ticker) Nothin' yet.  I got a good one on the lead at Hialeah, but he's fadin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best we had was Cat's Eye in the second at Del Mar, and he was only 5-2.  Not many longshots comin' in today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Billie.  You ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie prepares to write on her pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the finish, it's Single Action by two, Fasanella second, Visitation third. (reading up the sheet again) Line on Single Action... 3 to 2. Hell with it, that's no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie crumples up the piece of paper she's been writing and chucks it in a wastecan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need big odds on this one, J.J.  Take anything you get at 3-1 or better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff leaves the room, as Singleton turns back to his vigil at the ticker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little weary) Okay, the Fairfield Stakes at Santa Anita.  Mile and a quarter for 3 year olds and up.

dialogues.speaker: THE FLOOR AREA OF THE STORE
dialogues.text: Everyone is in his place as before.  Today, however, Curl Jackson is playing the part of the aging sport. Well scrubbed and clean shaven, he cuts a dashing figure his blue blazer and white pants.  We go to Gondorff in th cashier's cage.  He's talking to Niles, who's busy handin out fake bankrolls to members of the boost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gonna hit ya with 20 grand, Eddie.  How much cash we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not enough to cover a bet that big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a couple extra guys in the line, then.  We'll give him the shut-out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niles nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is still waiting.  He takes the 20 grand out of coat pocket and thumbs through it, just to make sure it's all there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singleton and Billie at the ticker again.  Billie looks a little sleepy.  Singleton is obviously involved with the progress of a race.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Billie, here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie snaps to and prepares to write as Singleton reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the wire it's Wrecking Crew the winner by five, Grand Theft second, Wingless third. (reading up) Wrecking Crew was...4 to 1. (ripping the sheet out of the ticker) That's our boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie and Singleton hustle out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Billie through the store and across the alley t the building from which Twist keeps his lookout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff, holding the ticker sheet Singleton has given hi emerges from the office and starts giving instructions to the boost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Furey, your horse is Wingless.  Paltrow, the Big Alabama and Phillips'll take Grand Theft. Rodgers and Eirie have Wrecking Crew.  Jackson -- His Dandy, Cowan -- Change of Heart, Fiskin and Chappie -- Made to Order. (pointing to the Eirie Kid) Eirie, he gets a bang outa seein' you lose, so we oughta use that on 'em.  If you play the birds of a feather routine we worked on, it should steam him up pretty good. You think you can handle that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little nervous) Yeh, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: O.K., you guys in line take your time, and I wanta see lotsa joy on Wrecking Crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie enters and gives Twist the piece of paper she wrot the race results on.  He picks up the phone and starts to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings and Lonnegan answers it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrecking Crew at 4-1, Grand Theft to place, Made to Order to show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan smiles and hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan's in line at the betting window.  There are four people in front of him this time, and they are moving rat slowly.  The "Last Flash" call is heard on the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting impatient) C'mon, let's hurry up there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man at the head of the line turns around and gives Lonnegan a chilling look, as if he were beneath contempt. He puts down $25,000 on Grand Theft.  The next man in lin plunges down $30,000 on Wrecking Crew. Just as Lonnegan is about to step to the window, Gondorff gives a quick signal to Singleton.  The speakers come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentlemen, this is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the $100,000 Fairfield Stakes at Hollywood Park in Los Angeles.  A mile and 3/8 for three year olds and up.  And they're off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting out his money) Twenty-thousand on Wrecking Crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  We can't take bets after the race is started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a sign above the window, which says exactly that.  Lonnegan grabs up his money in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it so hard, pal.  You probably woulda lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan wanders over to the bar in a funk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And around the first turn it's Wrecking Crew by a half length, Grand Theft second by one, His Dandy is third by one half, followed by Change of Heart, Back Flip, Made to Order and High Ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assembled patrons are once again thoroughly involved the race.  Eirie comes up to Lonnegan at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half-heartedly) Wrecking Crew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.  Maybe it's our day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan nods and wanders away.  Hooker comes over to him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get the bet down in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed) Oh, Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff and Niles, back in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out at the floor) Looks like he's sulking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we're lucky, this'll bring him back stronger than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming for home, it's Wrecking Crew by six lengths, Made to Order is second by two and a half, High Ground is third by a length and Grand Theft is coming fast on the rail.  It's Wrecking Crew, Made to Order and Grand Theft.  Wrecking Crew wins it by five lengths, Grand Theft is second by a nose, Made to Order is third by two.  Time for one and 3/8 mile, 2:11 and 4/10 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie explodes in a joyous frenzy.  He grabs Lonnegan by shoulders and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We won!  We won!  You hear that!  I won 30,000!  You hear that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, Lonnegan heard that.  Lonnegan shakes loose, grabs h coat and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He finds Hooker waiting for him outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell your friend I'll have the money here by post-time tomorrow. We'll take the first race where the odds are 4-1 or better.  And make sure I can get to that window this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I gonna do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coarsely) I don't know, figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan storms across the street to his waiting car and drives off.  Hooker relaxes into a smile.  He's already figured something out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker sits at the counter finishing a plate of meat loaf Loretta is down at the cash register, leaning on the coun looking idly out into space.  Hooker glances over at her every once in a while to see if she might be interested i striking up a little conversation.  She's not.  He finish his meal and comes down to the register to pay his bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meat loaf, apple pie and a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ringing it up) Sixty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker gives her a dollar.  She goes to the register for change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time you get off work here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doin' anything tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him his change) Yeh, sleepin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker figures that's enough of that.  He pockets his cha and starts out the door, when suddenly he stops short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street in a doorway is the silhouette of a man It's Cole.  He's pretending not to look at the diner, but Hooker isn't fooled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes back to Loretta at the register.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a back door to this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  What's wrong with the front?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgently now) Look, I don't have time to fuck around.  There's somebody out there I don't need to see.  You got a fire escape or anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, do me a favor.  Go into the bathroom, open the window and wait for me there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just do what I tell ya and everything'll be jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cracks of concern begin to appear in Loretta's marble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does this guy want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly) He'd like to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta just looks at him a second.  Realizing that this no joke, she turns and walks slowly but steadily to the bathroom.  Hooker waits until she's out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker goes to the front door and steps outside.  Cole lo up at the sound of the door.  Hooker makes a big show of spotting him, and runs back into the diner.  Cole, his co blown, draws his gun and races across the street in pursu Arriving just in time to see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker go into the bathroom, he charges in after him, onl to find the place empty.  He goes quickly from stall to stall, on the chance that Hooker might be hiding in one o them. He comes to one that's closed, and seeing a pair of woman legs under the door, rejects that, and moves on to the ne one. We cut inside the stall to reveal Loretta sitting on the toilet with her skirt hiked up.  Right behind her, crouch on the back of the seat, is Hooker. Cole has finished his rapid inspection now, and having fo nothing, looks around for Hooker's probable escape route. He sees the open window and climbs out to find himself in small air shaft, from which he knows Hooker could not esc Hooker, seizing the time, bursts out of the stall and run back out through the diner.  Cole sees him, but too late get off a shot.  He climbs back in the window and gives c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Hooker barreling down the street with Cole a hundred yards or so behind.  Hooker makes a sharp cut int an alley, and we see immediately that it's a hopeless dea end.  Inexplicably, he makes no attempt to run back out. Cole draws up and cuts into the alley, anticipating the k which should be easy now.  He prepares to sight down his victim, when suddenly he realizes there is no victim in sight.  Hooker, miraculously, has vanished.  Cole scans t alley frantically for some trace of him.  There are no windows or doors at the street level.  Not even a drain p Just brick wall.  It's impossible.  Hooker has disappeare into thin air. Cole slams his gun into his shoulder holster with a curse and starts back out of the alley, when all of a sudden he stops in utter terror.  His mouth drops open and he choke out the words:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salino, hey look.  I didn't mean to move in on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before anything else can come out, two bullets rip into h chest.  He falls to the concrete, coming to rest on a manhole cover, which we notice is slightly ajar.  We:

dialogues.speaker: THE SEWER PIPES
dialogues.text: Beneath the manhole.  We see Hooker making his way throug the slop, having gained another reprieve, but unaware tha with two down, there is still one to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker comes in the front entrance and goes to the elevat one of the old-fashioned kind with the iron grid on the inside.  He's still a little rattled and waiting for the elevator is making him restless.  It finally arrives, and steps inside, closing the grid behind him.  As he starts push the button for his floor, he realizes for the first time that he's not alone.  He looks to the corner to find Snyder, holding a gun on him.  This time there's not much doubt that he'll use it if necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder brings Hooker into the crate room where Capt. Polk and the other Agents are waiting.  Polk, as usual, has hi coat off, revealing his shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Hooker.  Captain Polk, F.B.I... (shoving a chair over to him) Have a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring it, drinking from a cup) You want a drink or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to talk to ya about Henry Gondorff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think I know him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well give yourself a couple seconds, crumb.  You wouldn't wanna lie to me.  Lt. Snyder here says you done a lotta griftin' in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Snyder doesn't know shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capt. Polk almost laughs, but he checks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got nothin' on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get it, and if we can't, we'll just make it up.  Grand larceny, extortion. (with special emphasis) Counterfeiting, anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker says nothing, but it's not from defiance now.  He' beginning to get the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I got nothin' against you, but you're in trouble here.  All you gotta do is tell us when Gondorff's gonna play his chump. We come in at the sting, make the pinch, and you walk out free as a bird.  No questions, no court appearance, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've already done time twice, and judges don't like three time losers. You wanna sit in the can for forty years, startin' tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make parole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell.  You won't even get a review till you're seventy.  And if the board starts to go soft, we'll let ya out in the yard some night with a hard-nose young bull who'll put fifty slugs in your face and ask what you were doin' there later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker wants to come back with something, but can't find

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be a sap, kid.  You could save us a little trouble.  But Henry Gondorff is through whether you help us or not.  There's nothin' left to do now but save yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's thoroughly whipped.  He sits down for the first

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Will you wait until the chump is played?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yes.  We don't care about the mark.  He deserves what he gets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with heat) I mean completely played.  Until he's beat and the score is taken. You come in before we beat him and I'll kill him.  You'll have a tough time explaining that, won't ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Hooker, but you take it on the lam, and we'll shoot you down on sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) Just as long as I get to finish the play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff and Hooker are playing gin rummy and drinking. Gondorff makes little comments as he plays, but Hooker is quiet and withdrawn.  The carousel is not in operation an heavy silence hangs over the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, kid?  You're not sayin' much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little nervous, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luther always told me to bite my toenails when I get nervous.  You see yourself doin' that and you realize it ain't worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker smiles feebly. Billie appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are a little slow tonight, Henry.  I wanna open the round for the girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff takes out a set of keys and tosses them to her. She leaves to go start the merry-go-round.  Gondorff sett back into the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, you won't lose him now.  We had him 10 years ago when he decided to be somebody.  Believe me, I've seen enough to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) How many guys you conned in your life, Henry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two or three hundred I guess. Sometimes played two a day when I was in Shea's mob.  We had it down to a business. (pause) 'Course Chicago was a right town then.  The fix was in.  The dicks took their end without a beef.  All the Wall Street boys wanted to make investments for us.  Even had marks looking us up, thinkin' they could beat the game. (pause) Yeh, kid, it really stunk.  No sense in bein' a grifter if it's the same as bein' a citizen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff chucks his cards on the table.  He's through for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better do some packin'.  I'm gonna be a hot number again after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why you doin' it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems worthwhile, doesn't it? Maybe it's just for the cave-in on Lonnegan's face when we put in the sting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good enough.  Hooker gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apologetically) I appreciate your stickin' your neck out.  I wouldn't have asked ya if it weren't for Luther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't nothin' gonna make up for Luther, kid. (pause) Revenge is for suckers.  I been griftin' 30 years and never got any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker just nods and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow him past the Carousel which is now full of gigg prostitutes in various stages of undress.  Their childish frolicking is charming from a group usually so jaded, but it's lost on Hooker tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late now and the street is deserted save for an occasional derelict or streetwalker on her way home from night's work.  We pick up Hooker coming down the street toward his apartment building.  He walks slowly, almost reluctantly, as if he didn't care whether he ever got the or not. As he nears his building, he notices Loretta coming out o the diner across the street.  He stops and watches as she looks up and disappears into an adjacent building that advertises rooms for rent.  After a few seconds, we see a light come on in one of its second story windows. Hooker just stands there a second, debating with himself, trying to figure out a reason for doing what he's going t do anyway.  We follow him across the street to Loretta's building and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes up the stairs to the room where the light came on He passes a couple of derelicts on the way.  He knocks tw and Loretta answers in her bathrobe.  She is more than a little startled to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he missed ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeh, this time anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta notices an old busybody peeping out at them from room across the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mrs. Hillard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hillard quickly closes her door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shuffling a little) I, ah...thought you might wanna come out for a while.  Maybe have a drink or somethin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You move right along, don't ya.
