dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with more innocence than confidence) I don't mean nothin' by it.  I just don't know many regular girls, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you expect me to come over, just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I expected somethin', I wouldn't be still standin' out here in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loretta looks at him carefully.  She knows it's not a lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with less resistance now) I don't even know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) You know me.  I'm just like you... It's two in the morning and I don't know nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two just stand there in silence a second.  There's nothing more to say.  She stands back and lets him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record spinning lazily on an old phonograph.  We hear Robert Johnson's "Come On In My Kitchen." Gondorff is sitting up in bed, with his hat on, lost in thought.  Bil is curled up asleep next to him.  There's a packed suitca next to the bed.  Billie wakes up and turns over a second

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Henry, knock off.  You've done everything you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff nods his agreement like a zombie and goes right thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LORRETA'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Hooker and Loretta are asleep against each other, their bodies illuminated every few seconds by the light from a neon sign across the street.  We dolly to the window and move in on another window in the building next door.  The no light on in it, but we can discern the basic outline o face behind the curtains, which are slightly parted to afford a view of Hooker's room by a black-gloved hand. "I said come on in my kitchen Cause it's gonna be rainin' outdoors."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music ends.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: We open on Hooker in bed, the morning sun streaming in on his face.  He awakens slowly, looks at the ceiling for a second and, remembering last night, turns to the side to find that Loretta is no longer there.  Still drowsy, he g out of bed and looks around the room for a note or some evidence of her continued presence.  He opens an empty closet, then opens empty drawers.  Finding nothing, he suddenly hits on another possibility, and looks in his wallet.  The money is still there.  Almost disappointed, slumps down in a chair, as the harsh reality of what will happen this day floods back in on him.  Music begins and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the black-gloved hand opening a small wooden box. Wrapped inside is a shiny black revolver, at this point i two pieces.  The hand reaches in and takes them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is poking at a plate of waffles and sausage.  The waitress on duty is not Loretta and Hooker has noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff is standing in front of the bathroom mirror, putting on his tuxedo.  He goes to his dresser, pulls out very small gun and tucks it in his cummerbund.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUNNMAN'S ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: The hand swirls a pipe cleaner inside the barrel of the revolver and picks some lint out of the chamber.  He then screws the barrel onto the body.  This is all seen in clo

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Hooker now has his tuxedo on.  He takes two small rubber bladders out of a drawer and puts them in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan paces nervously around the room, looking at the clock.  Obviously waiting for something, he's getting extremely impatient.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUNNMAN'S ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: We watch the hand carefully loading bullets into the cham of the revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff emerges from his room carrying his suitcase.  He stops and looks up at the mezzanine where Billie is stand They smile sadly at each other and give a simple wave, having done this too many times to get sentimental about now.  Gondorff walks out of the building.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Hooker is busily stuffing all his possessions in a paper bag, lumping clothes with food, records and toilet articl

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN'S SUITE AGAIN
dialogues.text: Lonnegan goes to the door to admit Floyd and two assistan one of whom carries a large brief case.  Lonnegan takes t brief case to a table and opens it.  Inside is a half million dollars in cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the hand putting a silencer on the revolver.  The gunman puts the revolver up to his eye to check the align and for the first time we see the face that goes with the hand.  It is fully as menacing as we had imagined: Broad, flat nose, thick cracked lips, narrow eyes and cauliflowe ears.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S ROOM AGAIN
dialogues.text: Hooker is on the phone now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that he's talking to Captain Polk.  Snyder listens also.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S ROOM
dialogues.text: Hooker finishes the conversation, hangs up and goes to ta one last look at himself in the mirror.  Finding everythi in order, he grabs up his sack of possessions and leaves room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick him up emerging from the building, and follow him around the corner to a secluded alley which he generally takes on his way to the store.  As he walks along, he notices Loretta coming toward him from the other end.  Sh wearing a coat, obviously on her way somewhere.  As she comes closer, we move to reveal the gunman appearing sudd in the alley behind and to the right of Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gunman quickly takes out his revolver, braces it in t crook of his hand, and takes careful aim.  Loretta sees h The gunman fires.  Loretta falls dead on the asphalt. Hooker spins around in confusion.  The gunman moves quick toward him.  Hooker starts to back up but the gunman stop when he gets to Loretta.  He kicks her over to reveal a g under her body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was gonna kill ya, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is stunned.  He can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dragging the body over behind a trash can) Her name's Loretta Salino. Lonnegan's people set her up in the diner.  C'mon, let's get outa here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker wants to stay and try to figure it all out, but th gunman drags him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polk, Snyder and several federal agents are busy putting their shoulder holsters, and checking their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Snyder) Whoever Gondorff's playin' for is bound to be a wheel.  As soon as we're inside, I want you to get the guy outa there as fast as possible, before the reporters show up.  We can't afford to embarrass any big shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan, carrying the brief case personally, is seen getting into his limousine.  Four assistants get in with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff enters the store carrying his suitcase.  Several the boost are already there.  Gondorff clasps his hands t generate a little enthusiasm.  He's obviously up for this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker sits in the back seat with the gunman right next t him.  He's still very uneasy with this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She coulda killed me last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many people coulda seen ya go in her room.  She was a professional. Used to work in the Dutch Schultz gang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff asked me to look after ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I know you're tellin' the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have much choice, do ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go to Hooker.  No, he doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Polk, Snyder and the other federal agents comi out of the warehouse in their white skimmers, and piling into cars.

dialogues.speaker: THE STORE AGAIN
dialogues.text: Niles is busily spreading "boodles" all over the cashier' area.  Singleton checks his microphone.  It works fine. checks it again.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN IN HIS LIMOUSINE
dialogues.text: He holds the brief case in his lap, his fingers tapping lightly on it.

dialogues.speaker: THE STORE AGAIN
dialogues.text: Hooker and the gunman enter and go over to Gondorff, who breaks into a wide smile.  Hooker returns it halfheartedl still ill at ease about what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: THE F.B.I. CARS ON THEIR WAY
dialogues.text: There are four or five driving in a column.  Snyder and P ride together in the back of the lead car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan's limousine pulls up outside, and the bodyguards pile out.

dialogues.speaker: THE STORE AGAIN
dialogues.text: Gondorff, Hooker and the others waiting, the tension expressed in their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan sits tensely in the usual booth.  He keeps both hands firmly planted on the brief case.  The phone rings Lonnegan goes to it.  Music ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place it on Syphon at 8-1.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan hangs up with the look of the financial killer. Eight to one odds is more than even he could have hoped f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Lonnegan across the street and into the store. The bodyguards remain outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is buzzing with activity.  Money and booze are everywhere.  The sheet writer and the boardmarker can har keep up with the action.  Lonnegan walks quickly to the betting line and finds to his relief that there's only on man ahead of him.  The man puts $25,000 on King's Image. Lonnegan steps to the window, swings up the brief case, a opens it for Niles to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight-faced) Five hundred grand on Syphon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niles is struck dumb.  He's never seen that much money be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing the flustered clerk) Hold on, I'll have to get the manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niles goes and returns with Gondorff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to the brief case) He wants to put a half million on Syphon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff looks at the money a second and then looks up at Lonnegan like he's gotta be crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uneasily) I can't lay that off in time.  We lose a bet that big, it could break us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (challenging) If ya win it could make ya, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Niles) What are the odds on Syphon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff looks at Lonnegan long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half mill on an eight to one shot. You're dumber than I thought, Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're more gutless than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words "Last Flash" are heard on the speaker.  Gondorf looks at Lonnegan with utter contempt.  He turns to Niles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chopped) Take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Niles hurriedly writes out a slip for 500,000 dollars. Lonnegan, allowing himself a sly smile, picks it up and retires to a nearby table.  He flashes a little okay sign Hooker who acknowledges it with a nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, this is Arnold Rowe, your caller for the San Antonio Handicap at Pimlico in Baltimore -- A mile and 1/16 for three-year-olds.  And they're off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan takes a deep breath and leans forward in his cha the larceny boiling in his veins.  Hooker looks to Gondor Gondorff gives him the "office." Hooker has to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And around the first turn it's King's Image by a neck, Syphon is second by one, Key to the Vault third by one half, followed by Mr. Moonlight, Red Ridge, Moneyman and No Charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly, Kid Twist bursts in through the entrance. Barely able to control his enthusiasm, he hurries over to Lonnegan's table and sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, but I just couldn't wait. Did everything go all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning for him to keep his voice down) Take it easy.  Everything's all right.  I put it on Syphon, on the nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in utter horror) On the nose!  I said place.  Place it on Syphon.  That horse is going to run second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan looks like he's just been stabbed.  He vaults ov the table to the teller's window and grabs Niles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me my goddamn money back! You hear me?  There's been a mistake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir.  The betting's closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan begins to shake him violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You give me my money back.  There's been a mistake, do you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff leaps to Niles' aid when suddenly there is a cra at the entrance door, and Polk, Snyder and eight federal agents burst into the room, guns drawn.  The place falls silent except for the loudspeaker, the members of the boo afraid to move.  Gondorff and Niles look at each other wondering how this could have possibly happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning to Hooker) All right, Hooker, you can go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's eyes go to Gondorff, who looks back at him in ut disbelief, the betrayal raging in his features.  Hooker, unable to meet his gaze, lowers his head and starts to wa out.  Almost unnoticed, there's a flash of movement at Gondorff's belt.  A small gun.  A shot.  Hooker clutches back and falls dead on the floor, the blood spurting from his mouth.  Polk, reacting instantly, pours four shots in Gondorff, who goes down in a heap.  Pandemonium breaks lo The members of the boost race for the door.  Lonnegan is totally stunned.  First he lost his money and now he's involved in a murder.  Snyder rushes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon.  We gotta get you outa here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder drags him through the crowd and out onto the stree where an F.B.I. car is waiting.  His bodyguards have long since fled at the sight of the F.B.I. men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My money's back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll worry about that later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder gets in beside Lonnegan, and the car speeds away.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE STORE AGAIN
dialogues.text: The pandemonium has now ceased.  Those who could escape have; the rest are lined up against the wall in frisking position.  Gondorff and Hooker lie on the floor dead.  Th loudspeaker drones on.  Singleton is still calling the ra from his booth, apparently oblivious to what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the winner is King's Image by four lengths, Syphon is second, by two, Moneyman third by two and one half.  Time for 1 and 1/16 miles, 1:21 and 2/10 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Polk walks slowly over to Hooker's body and bends down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker opens his eyes and slowly drags himself up off the floor, spitting out a little rubber bladder, filled with blood, that he's had in his mouth.  Gondorff does likewis Niles, Twist, Singleton and the rest of the boost begin t laugh and shake hands, as do the Federal Agents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Polk) Nice con, Hickey.  I thought you were Feds myself, when you first came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, Henry.  Snyder went for it all the way. (laughing) You shoulda seen the rag he lit under Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's take this place apart and get outa here.  You can get your splits from Eddie at Boudreau's tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff walks over to Hooker, who's wiping the blood off his face and hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You beat him, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) You were right, Henry.  It's not enough... But it's close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanta wait for your share?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'd just blow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff nods, and walks slowly to behind the bar.  He co out with his suitcase in one hand and Hooker's paper bag another.  He throws the paper bag to Hooker, who stops by the door.  Eirie Kid is standing there.  Hooker gives the "office" to Eirie, who beams and gives it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Hooker and Gondorff leave.  We hold on them, two ragtail grifters again as they walk off down the street a disappear around the corner.
